country:
None
text:
SUPERB beef stew!  I took the great base recipe, and tweaked it with a compilation of reviewer recommendations.  The end result is a winner, to be sure.  Here is what I did (and I won't change a thing the next time I make it): 1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt.  Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag.  Shake beef in bag to coat.  Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned.  Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften.  Transfer to slow cooker.  2.  Mix beef broth (I used Swanson's Certified Organic in aseptic carton) with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine.  Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker.  3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions:  increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.  Your home will smell wonderful all day, and your meal will be a savory feast!  I served the stew in bowls, accompanied by slices of fresh, crusty bread.

text:
I have been making this stew for almost 3 years and wanted to review it again.  Although I'm sure Corinne's suggestions are good, what I like most about this recipe is the simplicity of preparation...no browning the beef.  I've made this over a couple dozen times at least - doubled - and have never had leftovers.  It is a terrific recipe as written.

text:
THIS is a terrific basic recipe!!  Nothing to stop you from adding your favorite things - although the TASTE is GREAT just like it is.  I used chuck because it's not as dry as a bottom round.  I had a tomato so I chopped it up & added it.  I saw where someone had added an envelope of beef gravy - great idea too!!!  Thank goodness there's people out there REALLY KNOW HOW TO COOK!!  Oh, and don't bother to brown the beef the way some recipes state - it only makes the beef dry.  Thanks for this recipe.

text:
An excellent and easy stew recipe. I make minimal changes (I like parsnips, so I add three chopped in place of celery, and I add a little more broth because I like more gravy), but that's about it. This is one of those easy, homey, stick-to-your-ribs recipes. Some of the reviews tick me off: Yes, it's a "regular" stew recipe because it is, after all, STEW. And all the changes that other reviewers make? Don't say "I made this recipe, but I changed EVERYTHING about it." You aren't doing this recipe justice.. heck, you aren't doing THIS recipe at all. I'm as guilty of changing recipes to suit my tastes and pantry as much as anyone, but at least tell us that you've made the original recipe as written before doing your million-and-one changes! Thanks for sharing this tasty-as-written recipe, Buchko!

text:
I made similar adjustments to previous raters.  I dredged the beef in flour/salt/pepper and pan friend until browned in olive oil before adding to the slow cooker.  Then I added some butter and onion to the pan and cooked until softened. Next I deglazed the pan with some of the broth being sure to  scrape up the yummy bits. In total I used 2 10 oz cans of beef broth.  I added 10 oz. sliced button mushrooms. Used almost 2T worchestershire sauce, added a bunch of extra herbs and finally thickened with cornstarch.  It was perfect.

So you dont have to search for it, here is her suggestion: 1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.

text:
The comments about tweaking the recipe, such as browning the meat first and deglazing (not even sure what that is) are nice, but the basic recipe worked out very well for someone who doesn't have time to cook. I like that the recipe is simple for those of us who only have 20 minutes in the morning to throw things in the cooker before running off to work and want to come home to a nice, hot homemade meal. The stew turned out very well and was tasty. I'm not a chef and don't claim to be, which is why I turn to this site for finding recipes like this that are quick to prepare and taste good with a minimal amount of work. This stew does the trick- I have it with some fresh crusty bread  that I pick up on the way home and it makes a satisfying meal for my husband and I after a long day's work.

text:
Excellent!  VERY thick stew, so if you like a little bit of juice, increase the water.  I used inside round sirloin marinating beef (didn't have stewing beef on hand, and this is leaner than stewing beef).  I added an extra 1/2 cup of water, an extra celery stalk, frozen peas (during the last hour of cooking) and more potatoes to ensure that it was filling enough for four hungry adults.  It was polished off!  Double this recipe if you have more than four adults, or if you want some leftovers.  I served it with Maritime brown bread and cheese - yummy!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This was a great start for my tweeking, which I always seem to do! With no changes it still would have been at least 4 stars, it just needed some extra flavors.  First added a little more veggies substituting red potatoes. I dredged the meat in flour, salt & pepper, then pan fried in a little olive oil for only 5 minutes just until brown on all sides.  Removed the meat to the crock pot and deglazed the pan with beef broth and some red wine.  Added in some Mc Cormicks stew seasoning, rosemary, thyme and parsely. Increased the Worchestire sauce to 1 T. Then about an hour before done (about 11 hours) added a C. of fresh mushrooms.  This turned out great!  Perfectly thick for pouring over some mashed potatoes.  Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
This is a great beef stew recipe (as written). It's easy, doesn't make a lot of dishes, makes the house smell amazing, and my family loves it! I contemplated adding a thing or two the second time I made it, but I decided it was unnecessary. The flavors are great just using the base recipe. And really, why make more work for yourself by adding steps that aren't needed. Try this recipe as-is the first time you make it! You'll save yourself some work and I don't think you'll be disappointed.

I do have to say that it seems strange to me that people would give a recipe a 5 star rating, but they changed it so much that it's not the same recipe any more. It helps to rate the recipe as it's written. Not to mention that you should at least try it the way it's written before making all kinds of changes. As someone who's pretty new to the site, it makes it harder to find good recipes. Just my two cents.

text:
YUM!!! I made just a few minor changes to the original recipe and it turned out incredibly delicious!... First off, there's no need to brown the meat first like some reviewers suggested. I just dumped the raw meat into the crockpot and added the flour and pepper and I also added a packet of McCormick Beef Stew Seasoning Mix (I didn't add the salt)... Then I poured in one 14.5 oz can of beef broth, mixed it up really well, and added all the other ingredients exactly as listed (minus the 1 1/2 cups beef broth, of course)... In addition, I also added a tablespoon or so of chopped fresh parsley and a little more of the carrots, potatoes and celery than what the recipe called for, as it didn't look like there were enough veggies in relation to the meat. I used baby carrots and small honey gold potatoes, cut in half... I cooked the stew on high for 6 hours, stirring it every hour or so, and it came out PERFECT! It was very flavorful and just the right consistency. Definitely my favorite beef stew recipe EVER, and it was sooooo easy to make!

text:
Stew to die for!!! I used so many of other reviewers' suggestion-too many to mention, which turned out the most scrumptious stew I've ever made. Key improvements that made it great: Brown the floured beef first, use 3 c. beef broth or water/ water/bouillon combo, add Lawry's Beef Stew packet, add 1 cup frozen peas about 10-15 min. before finishing cooking. Prior to finding this recipe, I used only Lawry's Beef Stew packet, following the printed recipe. This recipe (with the tweaks) is soooooo much better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good.  I have been making this same basic recipe for around 15 years. The only thing that is different about my recipe is that it asks for more salt (1½ tsp), and only ¼ tsp of pepper. I also carefully stir in cooked peas at the very end before serving. And I am telling you, if you can refrain from eating it the first day, it is much better the second day!!!  And if you like the consistency to be thicker, you can thicken it with a basic roux. After cooking the stew, remove all food and leave the broth in the slow cooker and turn the cooker to high. In a separate pan, melt and cook 3 Tablespoons butter and 3 Tablespoons flour for around 5 min. Add this roux to the broth in the slow cooker and whisk it until you like the consistency. Add the food back into the slow cooker and enjoy.

Display Name:
DAYTEKMULTISYNC

city:

country:
None
text:
My husband is a picky eater and I did not have all the ingredients on hand, so here are the changes I made:  1 tsp of garlic powder (replacing minced garlic), no bay leaf, 1 tsp onion powder (replacing chopped onion) 2 cans beef broth (added a can of water as well, this helped make more base to the sauce), added about 1 cup baby carrots (replacing diced carrots), omitted celery, and added about 1 tsp or so of pepper.  These are just my personal changes, but the stew would be just as as good as the orginal recipe.

I made this at about 8 o'clock the night before...Our slow cooker has 3 settings - 'Keep Warm', 'Low' and 'High'.  'Low' is usually too high, so I turned it on 'Keep Warm' until about 7AM.  I found that the stew was not thickening up well and the beef was still pink, so I added about 1/3 cup Veloutine and turned it up to 'Low' and just prayed it wouldn't burn!

We turned it down to 'Keep Warm' again at 3PM and by dinner time it was absolutely perfect!  Two men and myself ate almost the whole pot (we all went back for seconds)!!!

Definately a keeper, 5 stars!!!  Great with biscuits!

text:
Very average tasting.  I could have bought a big can of Dinty Moore Beef Stew, liked it more, and saved a few bucks.  I followed the recipe as well as I could.  I had to double the beef broth because it had nearly dried up after about 3 hours on high.  Actually it was completely done after three hours on high for me - maybe my slow cooker has some turbo switch I didn't know about.  The meat does not need browned prior to placing in the slow cooker as some people have reported doing - it comes out as tender as possible.  The problem I had was with the flavor just being bland as some others have reported.  I will probably try again but will most likely add the beef stew seasoning pack others have recommended, and will do maybe two hours on high and two hours on low.  I would listen to those who put in the extra seasoning pack (McCormick's, I believe).  Good luck!

A few clicks later I found this recipe and was so glad to see that I didn't need to take the time to brown the meat.  Dumped the flour, salt, pepper and garlic in a large ziplock baggie, tossed in the meat, poured it into the cooker. chopped up the veggies added the remaining ingredients and off I went. text:
Sometimes adding wine too early in a recipe can leave a sour taste with the finished product. Many times I will add wine 1/2 to 45 minutes prior to the end of cooking. I avoid grocery store wines altogether (as they contain a ton of sodium and taste awful) and I never use a wine for cooking that I wouldn't drink. :) De-glazing pans with wine is a good idea for recipes that cook on the stove top for shorter amounts of time. Other ideas for this recipe: Always tenderize stew meat (pound cubes) and then shake them in seasoned flour before browning them. Tenderizing really does make a difference in tenderness.  I never used to brown my meat so as to "save time".  I realized, after browning my meat first, that I will NEVER skip this step again as the taste differential is very noticeable. The only other recommendation that I would make is more garlic and a couple of bay leaves (remove prior to serving).  The house smells wonderful when I make this recipe. Such a great comfort food for a cold winter's day!

text:
EXCELLENT & DELICIOUS.  I had only 1 lb stew meat which I cut into 1" cubes. Followed all other instructions.  My slow cooker is 'large' so I adjusted recipe for 2 plus extras for leftover: I used 2 cups left over corn beef broth, plus 1 can low sodium beef broth; 3 med red potatoes, cubed; 1/2 lb peeled baby carrots; 1 4oz can button mushrooms; 1 cup frozen peas. Cooked on high for 3 hrs, then low for 2 hr: total 5 hrs. 10 to 12 hrs is WAY TOO long for this recipe.   I added the mushrooms & peas the last 1/2 hr of cooking; then thicken liquid with 1 Tbl flour & broth. Switched cooker to 'warm' till ready for dinner.  New cookers power are higher than the old ones so food cooks a lot faster and more evenly.  Meat was tender, and veggies were perfect. Reviewers that state their meat was not tender, or that veggies were overcooked should check with the mfg of their cooker.  I was informed by my mfgr that the UL CODE was changed to cook at higher temperatures to insure that foods were cooked thoroughly to prevent bacteria or food poisoning.  That was good to know because you have to learn NOT to overcook, and come home to a burned meal.  I suggest that you check with your mfgr for the correct cooking times.  All cookers are not alike.

text:
Don't look at any other beef stew recipies. This is Awesome ! This is the beef stew recipe that I will continue to use forever. I used a bottom roast that I cut up into 1.5" cubes myself. Total cooking time was 5 hours on high. I did follow the changes that a reviewer named Corinne made and I highly recommend that you do too. They are as follows... 1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth (I used Swanson's Certified Organic in aseptic carton) with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.  Thanks for the additions Corinne.

text:
This recipe does not need another glowing review, but it was good enough that it deserves one! While in reality, this is a good old, basic beef stew recipe, the beauty is in the cooking method - the crock pot AND that it does not call for browning the meat before slow cooking. While I don't add or subtract ingredients from this recipe, I do modify the ones that are there a little bit. I up the Worcestershire to 1 tablespoon and I use two to three cloves of garlic (just love that stuff!). I also dredge the meat in either flour (or corn starch sometimes) before placing in crock pot (I just think it is a bit easier this way, so just personal preference, no right or wrong way here). And because I adore cooked celery, I often add three stalks or so. So you see, no real changing of the recipe, just the amounts of some things to suit my family's tastes. Make exactly as is and you won't be disappointed - tweak it a bit to suit you and your family and you have a stellar recipe in your repertoire!

text:
I've made this several ways. The first time I made it as Corinne suggested. It was a lot of extra work and I don't like salt. I don't recommend her way. The second time I made it, I made it as is. It was very, VERY good. My problem though was the amount of salt. Again, I don't like salt. The next time I made it, the third time, I eliminated the salt altogether. Because I do this, I usually have to add a couple of things to make up for it and in this case I did not. Needless to say, it was a bit bland. The fourth time I made it, I had great success! Again, I eliminated the salt. I added 2 tsp of sodium free beef bouillon powder, 1 tsp of onion powder, about 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes, a pinch of rosemary and 3 cloves of minced garlic. This one was a keeper. If you like salt, then the original recipe will is perfect. If not, then this last way may be something you'll enjoy. What is great about the original recipe and this last way is how easy and low mess it is. There is no reason to brown the meat in advance and this way the meat came out incredibly tender. Thanks for sharing this recipe! Our family loves it.

I made this 2 days in a row. My family thoroughly enjoyed this. I took the great base recipe, and tweaked it with a compilation of reviewer recommendations. The end result is a winner, to be sure. Here is what I did (and I won't change a thing the next time I make it): 1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into a zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth  with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning. Your home will smell wonderful all day, and your meal will be a savory feast! I served the stew in bowls, accompanied by slices of fresh, crusty bread.

I love this recipe as is. It's also SUPER easy to tweak. The only thing I would say (because of some of the other recommendations here) is DO NOT brown the beef first, it just ends up dry and tough. I tried quite a few different recipes that called for browning the beef first and the first time I made it with THIS recipe the beef just falls apart so soft and tender. Seriously just try it this way at least once. It's amazing.

This beef stew also does really well with mushrooms added, my husband loves mushrooms. I also add quite a bit more worcestershire because I love it. But every time I make beef stew I do this basic recipe and then add whatever I want and it always turns out great.

text:
Soooooo good.  Definitely do NOT need to go all crazy with browning meat, and DO cook on Low for the longer time period instead of trying to speed things up by putting it on High.  I made it both ways, and while I still enjoyed it when I put it on high, it made a difference in the meat texture and turned out perfectly when I cooked on low, as suggested.  I like mine to have more broth, so I made sure my ingredients were covered in beef broth (about 5 or 6 cups I think).  I added a glug of red wine, 1/4 tsp salt straight into the broth (in addition to the 1/2 tsp mixed into the flour already), and I put in 1.5 - 2 tablespoons of soy sauce instead of the worcestershire sauce (I made this recipe gluten free with gluten free soy sauce and gluten free flour).  Use red potatoes because they won't turn mushy on you.  It's the simple flavors of this recipe, cooked to perfection, that make this a great recipe.  It's like your grandma's best, classic Beef Stew. Definitely going to be a staple in my house.

text:
Excellent as is. I also add 1/2 pack of onion soup mix, a tsp of dried thyme, mushrooms, and frozen peas. Perfect with warm crusty bread. The most recent time I made this, I quadrupled the recipe and froze 3 portions in large freezer bags and made the 4th in the slow cooker. For the frozen meals, I just marked how long to cook on the bag before filling. When I wanted to make the stew, I would thaw it in the fridge overnight so that the next day I could just pop it in the slow cooker.

Display Name:
MTPURSE
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I knew this was a good starting point.  What I did differently was coat the meat with the flour, salt and pepper and then fry it in dijon mustard flavored oil.  I put the potatoes, carrots, celery and onion on the bottom of the crock to be sure they would cook completely and put the meat over it.  I didn't have any beef broth so I took the trimmings from the meat cubes and boiled them for a few minutes along with a package of onion soup mix.  Remove the meat scraps since they're just stringy, and pour the resulting broth over contents in the crock after sprinkling with paprika and adding the worcestershire sauce, garlic and bay leaves (yes, more than one leaf).  No need to stir.  Then, about a half hour before it's done, add a can of stewed tomatoes, some mushrooms and about a cup of frozen peas.  Okay, now you can stir.  If it's too juicy for you, just do the corn starch/water mix and add it.  I made two batches, one in a 3.5 qt. crock pot and one in a 5 qt. slow cooker.   Both were done in about 4 hours on high doing it this way.  Bon apetit.

I have to agree with susanna's review. I hope I don't offend anyone when I write this: I know we all "tweak" sometimes - like I added 3 tablespoons of tomato paste and extra veggies and broth, but to change the recipe THAT much is to not make this recipe. Beef stew is supposed to be simple and great tasting - this recipe is both as it is written. As a busy mom of 3 kids, it is perfect. I will say I tried beef stew with red wine and my kids hardly touched it - it took away from the true taste of the stew. If you want beef stew like you had as a kid, this is it. The simplicity and reminder of home make this a 5 star recipe. Thanks so much for sharing!

country:
None
text:
A very savory stew with NO leftovers!  My whole family gave it "two thumbs up".  Personally, I would cook this stew NO LESS than 12 hours on the low setting.  The meat was "fork tender".  I did scale the recipe to yield 8 servings, evenly browned the floured meat 1st in margarine, then transferred it over to the crock pot.  I also included 2 cups of water and 2 cups of beef stock for a heartier flavor and more gravy in the stew.  Additionally, I used a TBLS more of Worcestershire Sauce, (1) TBLS of Lawry's Seasoned Salt, 1 tsp. of sugar and more black pepper to taste.  Lastly, I blended 3 TBLS each of real butter and flour and "whisked" it into the stew w/a fork the last 2 hours of cooking time, to thicken the gravy.  Absolutely delicious with either crusty bread or hot, buttered cornbread fresh out the oven.  Next time, I'll add frozen peas the last hour or so.  Overall, this one will definitely remain in my recipe file.  I plan to make this stew again real soon!

text:
Great! If you like VERY meaty stew, this is the recipe for you!  I like a little more of a balance between meat and veggies so I add 6 carrots, 2 large russet potatoes, and 3 stalks of celery. I double the garlic and use an extra cup of beef broth. No need to brown the meat or saute the onions 1st, it's a slow cooker recipe! The meat is going to be fall apart succulent anyway you do it.  Also don't add red wine...it adds a sour flavour to it that's just off.  I served it with a dollop of cream cheese on top (if you have not tried this DO...you'll never eat beef stew again without it) and crusty bread  Thanx Buchko!

The original recipe isn't bad, but with some alterations it can be superb! 1/2 C red wine gives it flavor, and increase the flour to 1/3 C to compensate for the extra liquid. Use at least a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce, and two each bay leaves and garlic cloves. We halved the onion and added a jar of those small "Holland-style" onions, but the veggies are flexible. Make sure to be bold with the flavoring, though! Delicious with crusty bread.

text:
EXCELLENT!!  I followed the recipe with Corinne's recommendations from 10/10/06.  She said to increase flour to 1/3 cup.  I also added Morton's Nature's Seasoning, garlic powder, and onion powder.  Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker.  I mixed 1/2 cup of the broth with some Swanson's concentrated broth jellies (2 of them) and the worcestershire sauce and deglazed the pan.  I poured that into the slow cooker and added the remaining 1 cup of beef broth.  Add the remaining ingredients (I also added fresh green beans because I had them on hand).  Increased the garlic to 2 cloves minced.  I mixed everything in the crock pot and let it go on high for 4 hours.  The meat was amazingly tender and the veggies were flavorful.  The browning of the meat makes all the difference.  This is a keeper!

text:
My husband said this is the BEST stew I have ever made.  Even 4 stew skeptics (kids under the age of 9) devoured it.  I also floured the beef, using top sirloin, not stewing beef, browned in a bit of oil and butter, then put them to the side and sauteed onions, adding carrots, then celery, then garlic in that order (leaving a 2 minute gap between each addition), also deglazed with red wine, then threw everything into the crock pot.  I put it in the fridge then pulled it out in the morning and put it on before I left for work.  I think the top sirloin is way better than the stewing beef, came out extremely tender and not dry at all.  Also, I diced the celery so it pretty much dissolved into the stew, without being mushy or anything but you still got the flavour of it.

text:
I took the advice of other reviewers:  At the beginning, I added a package of gravy mix mixed with a cup of water, and tripled the amount of garlic.  With about an hour to go, I added a can of italian stewed tomatoes, a can of corn, a can of peas, and some sliced fresh mushrooms.  I did try to thicken it a bit with some cornstarch (for the first time ever -- but I think it worked!).  This was delicious -- we ate it over rice, with grated mozzarella cheese on top!  I added the cheese because I thought the pepper was a little too strong.  Next time, I'll put in less pepper and paprika, but everything else I'll do the same.

text:
This is the best stew recipe I've tried (and there were many tries)! My husband raved about it, all the kids gobbled it up in record time. I do want to say that there is no need to brown the beef before putting it in the slow cooker. In fact, it adds nothing at all to the taste or the tenderness. What it does add is more fat and calories. I wouldn't have thought that the best stew recipe on this site would have been the easiest, but the fact that you don't have to brown anything before putting it in the slow cooker is the beauty of this easy to make dish.

text:
I used all the ingredients listed with the exception of bay leaves because I didn't have any.  I really did consider using Corrinne's suggestions but figured I'd stick to the recipe as much as I could.  I was worried that this wouldn't turn out.  It was just okay.  It was definitely nothing to rave about and, in my opinion, is not worthy of the high rating it has.  Not as written, at least.  I seasoned the stew to my taste because it didn't have enough flavor.  I also added garlic powder, onion powder, and diced canned tomatoes.  After I added more spices and sampled a spoonful it tasted better.  But, I was very disappointed with the finished product because the stew meat was WAY too lean.  I mean, it was tender because I let this cook on low for about 10.5 or 11 hours, and the texture of the meat was just plain dry!  There was no "richness" to it.  Something told me to use the chuck roast instead, because it has fat throughout the meat, which would have provided a juicier, richer, flavor ... but I wanted to follow this recipe for the most part.  Big mistake.  So, while it was etable and not as bad and other people said it was, it just wasn't desirable and I will never make this again.

Exceptional! I am a pot roast/beef stew FANATIC (as a kid, it's what I always picked for my "birthday meal"), so I consider myself a tough critic. I've been making pot roast/beef stew myself for years now without a recipe, but decided to give this one a whirl. BEST POT ROAST I EVER MADE! Thank you so much for sharing this one. No modifications. Yum, and my house smelled incredible. One tip; do NOT shortchange yourself on the cooking time.

text:
This dish might rate higher than a two star when not overcooked, but I wouldn't know. I followed the recipe exactly, using a few modification suggestions from other reviewers (adding beef gravy packet). The problem I had was when I stuck to the 10-12 hour cooking time. I started cooking it on Low at around 7PM. I checked on it periodically until midnight, when I went to bed. It looked to be nearly cooked, but it was hours from the time the recipe said it would be cooked, so I let it cook the rest of the time overnight. By the time I turned off the crockpot at around 6:30 AM, it was overcooked and very close to being burnt. I would suggest that you cook it for probably no longer than 8 hours on low, and the suggested 4 hours on high. I have no idea why they think it takes so long to cook on low!

text:
This is a great recipe. I tried it last week and thought the meal was good. I altered it slightly this week and thought it was outstanding. With the alterations I now give it 5 stars.  Here's what I did: After tossing the beef in flour to coat I browned the beef in a skillet. I added the onions to soften. I then added half a cup of red wine to deglaze. I threw it all in the slow cooker after that and followed the recipe as written with one minor adjustment- I added a hearty tablespoon of Worcestshire sauce. With these minor changes, the stew had a much greater depth of flavor.  I think the key was to brown the meat first and also add the wine. Thanks for the great base recipe and for all of the user review suggestions. This stew is simply perfection!

I followed the suggestions of the other reviewers, browned the beef first (in batches), increased flour to 1/3 cup, and added 1/2 cup of red wine to deglaze the pan. I also added a little more red wine, 1/4 cup, to the pot just because it looked like it needed more "juice." I also used McCormick's Beef Stew seasoning in addition to the other ingredients in the recipe, which may be cheating, but hey, it tasted great. This was a very hearty stew, perfect for a cold winter evening. The house smelled so wonderful, I was hungry all day! I, too served it with a crusty french bread. Yum!

I always wanted a way to make a slow cooker stew without having to brown the meat first.  I prepped everything the night before, put the veggies in first, added a can of diced tomatos, some pieces of crumbled, cooked bacon with the meat, added some wine and balsemic vinegar with the broth, and at the end added a 10 ounce box of frozen mixed vegetables.  It was perfect!!

text:
SELF CONFESSED LAZY COOK
Ok there are few times I'll review. Either when it's really good or really gross. This dish is AWESOME. Chop it up. Bung it in the slow cooker. I use very lazy garlic.. but a real onion.  None of that celery nonsense. Bung another potato instead. Go to work, it's ready when you get home. Serve with a crusty bread and butter. Served family of 3 and lunch next day. Oh wow 2nd day tastes great too. Dishwasher friendly and very little mess (flour gets everywhere but that's just me). 
Look at me..  in the garden drinking a beer. The wife thinks I'm slaving in a hot kitchen making something special. 
Ha ha!

text:
I am so glad I found this recipe and read through some of the reviews before I made it.  I was tempted to try Corinne's version because I am a bit of a perfectionist when it comes to cooking.  I read more reviews and decided to stick to the original recipe.  It came out SO SO good and it was SO SO easy.    Here is a GREAT tip to make cleanup a little easier.  I used a crock pock liner (it's like a plastic oven bag and you toss it when you're done) to which I added my beef then the flour mixture and shook it up and the beef was coated evenly.  Then I put the bag with the beef and flour in the crock pot and added the rest of the ingredients.  Cleanup was basically non existent!

text:
First let me just say, I followed this recipe for the most part as written and I have no idea why the first top reviewer did what she did to it. I'm sure her stew came out great, however, this stew was DELICIOUS following the recipe posted. Totally unnecessary to do all those extra steps and ingredients. Because I used a little more beef than 2 pounds and put more potatoes, carrots, and celery then stated, I doubled many of the ingredients to make up for the added food. The only big changes I made were added a 6 oz can of tomato paste, and I did up my paprika to 2 TBSP as well as 2 TBSP worchester sauce and the stew was AMAZING!! What a great recipe. Oh, how could I forget, I love putting wine in any meat dish I cook, so I added a 1/2 cup of pinot noir. Perfection. My husband loved it so much, he was eating left overs after he finished his plate right out of the crock pot. Luckily I still had enough for dinner the next night. Thank you to the original poster for a great, simple, and TASTY recipe! It's getting added into my rotation of meals.

text:
Necessity/mother of invention and all that!  I've made this recipe before (must've forgotten to rate it), and followed Corrine's changes - excellent!  Yesterday, with a sick child at home and a package of stew meat to use up, I had to be inventive... and it was excellent again.  I had no beef broth, but did have an open box of vegetable broth to use up.  I added about 1 1/2 packets of beef seasoning from Ramen packages, which I was afraid would only add salt, but did seem to add some beefiness.  I also didn't have the McCormick Beef Stew packet (have never bought that) so I added in a package of Lipton's Onion Soup Mix.  No red wine, so I used white.  More garlic, full TBSP of worcestshire, and all the other changes as per Corinne (browning the beef, etc.), and it was so darn good that my family polished off 2 pounds of meat!  It was not overly salty as I had worried with all those soup/seasoning packets.  I did thicken the sauce a bit at the end as I had added a bit of extra broth and it was very thin.  I had a LOT of veggies and sauce leftover with no meat... so guess what's in the crockpot this morning? :-)  I'm cooking more meat to add in, and I think I'll throw in some peas today as well.  Very forgiving recipe/technique, and with a bit more garlic and onion, extremely flavorful.  I'd also like to say that I really do appreciate all the comments that add in changes - I rarely have exactly the ingredients on hand, and love the input of possible changes.  9/15/16 UPDATE -

text:
Awe-some! Made exactly the way user Corinne modified and it came out fabulous! By far, the best slow cooker beef stew recipe I've ever tried. Here are her modifications:  1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth (I used Swanson's Certified Organic in aseptic carton) with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.

text:
This was my first attempt at Beef Stew and it was a total hit!  I pretty much followed the recipes with the exception of a few minor chnages.  Since I was opening a can of beef broth I added the whole 2 cups, but after 2 hours on low I was afraid it might get runny so I added a Tablespoon of corn starch to thicken.  Next time I'll just use the 1 1/2 cups, I also added a little bit more Worchester sauce, a tad bit more salt and pepper to suit my tastes and i doubled the bay leaf.  Came out fantastic, don't brother with all the extra work of browning absolutely no need for it!  Thanks for the fantastic recipe.

text:
This is a huge hit in my house! Our son loved it...and he's NOT a stew eater. We like a 'brothier' stew, though, so I doubled all of the broth ingredients (beef broth, spices, etc.) as well as the flour for thickening. The first time I made it as is and it was more like beef and veggies with gravy. The second time it was more stew-like. Delicious either way, though! I also added a tablespoon of worchestershire sauce instead of a teaspoon (2 TBS for more broth). Thanks! It's great!

text:
I rated this recipe 4 stars, but if you follow Corinne's suggestions (another review) I would rate it 5 stars. I followed her advice in full. The only changes I made to the recipe was that I did not add celery (didn't have any), and toward the end of cooking I ended up adding about 3/4 cup of water because it was VERY thick stew.  The water thinned it out just enough to make it a nice thick stew (but not too thick). This stew had a very nice beefy flavor and very nice dark brown color. Very pleasing to the eye. Will definitely make again.

text:
I didn't brown the meat and don't think I will, either.  Why make more work?  It was plenty moist and tasty and fell apart like a good stew should.  I put all the dry seasonings (include a packet of Beef Stew seasoning) in a zip lock and tossed the stew meat in there till well coated.  Put that in the slow cooker with diced up potatoes, halved baby carrots, a can of beef broth, the garlic, paprika and worchestshire.  Went to work.  Came home for lunch and threw in some cut up portobello mushrooms.  Served with some Pillsbury Garlic crescent rolls for Halloween dinner before passing out candy.  Everyone loved it.  It's a keeper!

Very good homestyle recipe.  When you are craving some good 'stick to your ribs' comfort food, this is the meal.  In the future I think I will play with using fresh herbs and red wine, but as is it is very good too.

Great when served with biscuits hot out of the oven!

text:
I finally bought a slow cooker and wanted a good beef stew recipe to christen it. This really hit the spot! I skipped the onion and paprika, subbed baby carrots and red potatoes, and added frozen petite peas in the final hour. (Oh, and poured in a few glugs of cab sav.) It was ready in 8 hours on Low. (I had cut the meat and potatoes into pretty small pieces.) The gravy was thick, perfect for mopping up with hot rolls. I will be making this all the time this winter! Thank you, Nancy!

userID:
13069905
Display Name:
Aliqat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
92
recipesCount:

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as my base. I had a couple of big T-Bone steaks I cubed them then seared them in olive oil at med-high heat. Once they were seared I put them in the slow cooker. I used beef broth to deglaze my pan and added that liquid to the meat. 
I used 6 potatoes, 4 celery stocks, 1/2  large onion, baby carrots cut into 1/2" pieces. I minced 5 garlic cloves, 2 Tab of worstershire sauce, 2 packets of stew seasoning, 3 bay leaves, salt and pepper to taste put it all in the slow cooker on high for 5 1/2 to 6 hours then reduced to low. 
It was delicious, my husband and my parents who are visiting loved it . 
The only thing I'll do different next time is use a different cut of beef, I used a London broil last time put it in whole and after 10 hours it fell apart and I think it had a better taste. This is a great sit by the fire with a big bowl of stew to warm you up.

I thought it was very tasty, but when I did it for 4 hours on high all of the broth was gone and it was starting to burn, so just something to look for especially if you have new slow cooker because I have heard they get a lot hotter and can tend to over cook. Display Name:
Cheryl King

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6246071.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner tonight.  Yummy!  Made a few changes - some as suggested by others, some of my own.  Seared off the meat & deglazed the pan with the beef broth.  Pan needed further deglazing, so I added about 1 cup of water, the worscheshire sauce, and my own mixture of seasonings - celery flakes, steak seasoning mix, dried Basil, and some sprigs of thyme.  Also added the bay leaf to this mixture and let it simmer for a couple minutes before adding it to the beef already in the crock pot.  Some other changes I made - 3 stalks of celery instead of 1, about 8 oz. Mushrooms, and a small bag of frozen peas added about 1/2 hour before serving.  I cooked on high over night (a short night - 4 hours), refrigerated all day, and cooked on low for about 4 hours before serving.  This is a great recipe.  I love the addition of the worcheshire sauce as it gives a vinagery aspect to the stew (which my husband love but I'm not so fond of) without being as overpowering as vinegar would be.  This is my new go to for beef stew!

text:
Best Beef Stew ever! I usually just use the McCormick's Slow cooker beef stew packet and it always seems like something is missing. I decided to try something new, so I followed Corrine's suggestions and it was SUPERB! My husband said it was the best beef stew he has ever had. I used about 3 pounds of lean beef stew meat, and added a can of corn, a can of green beans, and a can of fire roasted tomatoes with juices in with everything else. YUM-O. I don't even like red wine but the flavor of the beef stew was fantastic! I was very nervous trying Corrine's changes but I am SO glad I did. You won't regret it. I can say that if I hadn't added the changes, this might have been too bland for me. I like a lot of flavor. hope this helps :)

I've tried a few versions over the years and I made this tonight and this was the best recipe I've ever had! I feel browning the meat first dries it out and toughens it so I prefer not to. The beef was shredded it was so tender! I added a drained can each of green beans and corn for more veggies in the last hour and didn't put the potatos in until 2 hrs left. I also thickened it with some cornstarch. Wonderful recipe and will be the one I always use.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I pretty much followed this recipe except I added a little bit more potato and some red wine. I was hoping to have it cooked before going to bed, get it in fridge for next day's dinner.

I cooked on hi for 5 1/2 hours and the potatoes and carrots were no where close to being done. I turned it to low, added a bit more broth and let it cook all night.

Stuck it in fridge and we heated it up for dinner that night. I used Spice Island Bay Leaf and we thought the bay leaf flavor was overpowering everything else. I think next time I will leave it out, or take it out halfway through cooking.

Other than that, it was delicious. I prepped the meat as the recipe states, I didn't  mess with browning it at first. What's the point of using a crock pot if you have to dirty up other pots and pans?

The meat was tender, the gravy/soup was delicious. The potatoes and carrots held up and didn't turn mushy.

Oh, and we added canned green beans when re-heating and that was a very nice addition.

Excellent beef stew; will make it again.

text:
Simple and tasty.  I added about 1/3 cup of red wine and a tablespoon of balsamic vinegar for a little extra flavour.  I didn't have a can of beef broth, so I used "Better Than Buillion', a wonderful organic beef paste.  I just ate a bowl fresh out of the crock pot on a cool autumn day - wonderful!  Oh yeah - and I used bison stew meat as that is what I had kicking around.

after tasting it, seemed to me like it was kind of bland, like missing some kind of saltiness. for asians, you might be familiar with fish sauce-- i added abt 1 tsp fish sauce (more to taste), & then it was good beef stew, not exactly the best i've had. didnt become "fishy-tasting" at all, took off the flatline in the taste. i would probably still make this with some mushrooms.

text:
I have had this recipe as written several times, and my family absolutely loves it.  By itself, with biscuits over it, reheated, there is no way to eat this that isn't delicious!  I do definitely recommend cooking it the longer, low heat, way though.  I was late putting it in today so did it on high, and it didn't thicken up quite as well as I'm used to.  Still delicious, but I do like a thicker gravy in the stew, personally.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe made an excellent stew.   I usually never rate a recipe unless I follow it exactly but I will in this case because I think you should know that you can play around with this one to suit your taste and end up with excellent results.  I browned the meat in oil first (because I like a "seared" look), used 1-1/2 cupes water with 1 extra large buillion cube (because I didn't have broth) and added 1 14.5 oz can stewed tomatoes and some fresh green beans (because I wanted to get rid of them).  This was excellent.  It could have used more gravy (because I did add the extra veggies) and would consider using more broth/water&bouillon/wine the next time.

text:
Wow, best I ever made!  I modified like others by first coating the meat with the flour,salt, pepper mixture, then browning it and deglazing the pan with 1/2 C. red wine.  I also added pkg. of McCormick stew seasoning once it was in the crock pot.  I usually don't use packages of seasoning, but this was just so darned good I wouldn't want to leave it out.  The gravy was a rich, dark brown and looked as good as it tasted.

text:
This was a very homey stew.  I made a few minor changes based on personal taste.  The changes I made from the written recipe were: 1 1/4 lb of stew meat, more carrots, more potatoes and 1 1/2 c more broth.  Changes that I added (again based on personal taste): in the last hour of cooking I added a can of corn, a can of green beans and a can of mushrooms.  I also added a packet of brown gravy and a dash of Kitchen Bouquet.  I was concerned about not browning the meat but it turned out very tender.  I cooked on high for 5 hours and then left in on warm for a couple of hours to finish thickening up.  The stew was served with fresh bread.  With the extra broth there was plenty of gravy to sop out of the bowl.

text:
This beef stew is wonderful.  I did however adjust it slightly.  I put the meat, flour, salt and pepper in a big baggie and shook it until all the meat was covered.  I then added about 1 tablespoon to a pan along with the onions and browned the meat.  There was a little of the mixture left in the baggie so I first dumped that into the crockpot and then added the meat and onion cooked mixture on top of that.  Then I followed the recipe.  About 1/2 way through cooking I thought it lacked a little something so I added 1 teaspoon of dried rosemary and 1 teaspoon of dried parsley.  That did it!  We LOVED this recipe and because it was so good, I made another batch just to share with others.

text:
This recipe is excellent!! It came out GREAT!! but I did make a few changes.. I did brown the meat on all sides real quick after coating the meat with the flour/spice mixture.. Added 1/12 cups of water and 1 beef bouillon cube to the pan I browned the meat in until disolved and poured over the meat. I also used 1 package of Onion soup mix And chopped up 1/2 onion and added to the crockpot. 2 celery stalks chopped about 1/4 inch pieces. added 1 teaspoon of chopped garlic, and used a small bag of baby carrots whole.. I didn't have any potatoes but canned whole potatoes and didn't want them to get mushy so I waited until the last 3 1/2 to 4hrs to add them since they were a little softer then fresh cut potatoes. I let it simmer the whole 9-10hrs and added a micture of 1/4 cup of Wondra quick mixing flour with about 1/4/ to 1/2 cup of hot water to make almost a pancake consistency and mix it in to the crockpot until blended.. It was Wonderfull!! Cant wait until tomorrow for left overs!! :)

BIANKAT

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/202178.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good start to the recipe. 5 star with my updates.  I made better, IMO, by browning the beef cubes first. Put a tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium high heat until shimmering. In batches, brown cubes of beef (don't crowd the beef because you don't want them to steam), then place into the pot. In between batches deglaze the pan with wine (~1/4C), then add the residue into the pot. Continue the oil, beef, wine process until all the beef is done.  Further, I doubled the broth because we like more liquid, added more garlic, and put in a few sprigs of thyme.  I let it cook on low for 10 hours (that's how long I was away at work - it would probably be fine a couple hours less). I then added an 8oz package of button mushrooms, quartered, and 1C frozen peas for the last hour or so. If necessary, thicken the gravy with a cornstarch slurry. Unbelievably tender and delicious.

This is a very good recipe, it has not finished yet, it has about 3 hours to go, but the broth is awesome. A tip I would like to share to making your meat tender is to soaking the meat in red wine vinegar preparation. The red wine really gives the meat a kick and the vinegar breaks the meat down to be more tender. I guarantee you will have the best beef stew doing so.

country:

text:
Wonderful recipe!  I made a few changes to the base recipe.  I love a very flavorful stew and wanted to make sure it didn't come out bland at the end.  I added an envelope of lipton onion soup and an envelope of mccormick's beef stew seasoning.  I also upped the garlic to 3 large cloves and added string beans.  At the end of the cooking time as another reviewer suggested I mixed a quarter cup of merlot with some corn starch and added it in and let it cook with the lid off for 15 minutes to thicken up.  This added merlot gave the stew a wonderful rich flavor and the extra seasoning made it anything but bland...it was just perfect!  It was delicious!  I served it with a crusty multi grain baggett.  I will definitely be making this again!

text:
I made this recipe with the modifications compiled by Corrine.  While the flavor was good, I wasn't a fan of the flour coating on the stew meat.  It gave the meat a somewhat 'slimy' outside.  Also, I believe due to the flour cooking all day in the stew the thickened sauce burned to the sides of the crock pot.  Next time, I think I'll brown the stew meat without the flour, then add the flour to the broth the last hour of cooking.  Overall, still pretty good.

text:
Hearty, basic, & easy! Leftovers reheated later in the week tasted great, too.
I made very minor changes:  I used 2 cans of beef broth, 2 stalks of celery, 1 Tbsp of Worchester, & 2 cloves of garlic.  S&P I added to taste.
I had some barley in the cabinet & I threw it in towards the end...it thickened it up to a nice "stew" consistancy.  
Great served with warm bread/rolls.

I really love this recipe.  It can be done all in one pot with very  little mess to clean up.  The taste is amazing, especially for how simple it is.  I did add a half cup of wine for extra savoriness but otherwise followed the recipe.  No need to brown the meat before hand makes this one a keeper and repeater. Everyone in our family enjoyed it and it will be a new staple in our house.

text:
I've reviewed all the other suggestions and I've made this a few times now. Trust me, FOLLOW THE ORIGINAL RECIPE! It's simple, it's easy to follow, and it's delicious! The ONLY change that I made to this was a added a bit more beef stock because I like a bit more "broth" to my beef stew....the original was just a bit to thick for me. I made a larger batch, with 3 lbs of stew beef so I adjusted the rest of the ingredients by 1/3. I also did double the amount of stock plus a little more flour to make up for it. That's it. This is a great recipe...don't mess with a good thing!

text:
This is a wonderfully simple one dish slow cooker meal. You can complicate it by brazing the meat or sauteing things first but it certainly is not necessary. That is the beauty of a slow cooker. I find this recipe to be basic and contain everything a good basic beef stew should have. Of course individual tastes vary and this recipe can support additions of ingredients that you prefer in your stew. 
Many times I do not have time to spend on our main meal but this recipe allows me to prepare a healthy meal even though I had to be away from home most of the day.

I think this is a great stew as is for anyone wanting a simple crockpot stew! The only change I made was adding some frozen peas. text:
Full disclosure, I added more broth (3 10 oz cans) because I prefer soup-like soup, as well as a packet of McCormick's beef stew seasoning.  Everything else I followed to the letter.  That being said, even with the extra spices I found this to be pretty bland.  The other reviews were right, this recipe lacks depth and layers.  I'm not sure what could have fixed it (more herbs and spices maybe) but it definitely needs some tweaks.  It is a good base to start with though if you're one of those cooks who can be creative in the kitchen.

text:
I tried this recipe for the first time today but it will not be the last time! It was fabulous! I only made one substitution and added two extra ingredients but otherwise, followed the original recipe. I added parsnips and turnip because my husband wouldn't consider it a stew if it didn't contain those two veggies. Then, because I had a stewing bone (I always use one for extra flavour) to put in with the meat, I didn't use beef broth. I just used the equivalent in water and it was very flavourful. Using water instead of broth makes for a less salty stew, I'm sure, but you can always add salt at the end if need be. It was SO GOOD. We loved it. Thanks for the recipe, BUCHKO!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a good base for those who are new to making a stew or to the crockpot.  For those who like to tinker, it is a great stew to tinker with.  As written it is rather bland, but can be made much more flavorful.  My tweaks are similar to Corinne's.  I also coat the meat in spices and flour then brown the meat before putting in the pot.  I also add 1/2 alcohol and 1/2 broth instead of all broth.  I have done it with a good hot paprika, but I like it best as a more Provencal stew, using a good red wine and herbs de provence.  I've also done an irish stew using a dark stout and irish garden herbs.  Both give a nice depth of flavor.

text:
Best recipe for beef stew I have found. Only I didn't need 12 hours, but it was done in 7 with my settings on low and had to stir every 1-3 hours otherwise gets a nasty black crust you have to scrape out. I think its the flour burning if not stired. Maybe because I have a newer crock pot and only used 1 pound of meat it was done sooner. Used 3-4 tablespoons of flour and a pinch of thyme. Used a bit more broth perhaps 2 cups?--until everything was covered. Usually use wine but found the recipe had a lot of flavor I didn't need it. Used yams instead because they are healthier. This stew gets salty after cooking so don't add extra salt until done. Bigger chunks of veggies might be better as they get smaller after cooking. Was very tasty when it came out so will be using this as my basic stew recipe from now on.

text:
I make this regularly in the winter and my husband and I both love it.  I use a few tweaks-- I up the spices to suit our taste, use whole wheat flour, and make the potatoes into bigger chunks.  I also found that I needed to adjust the timing for my crock pot. My cheat timing is to do one hour on high and 4 hours on low.  Thanks for the terrific recipe!

text:
I followed this recipe exactly and it came out very thick and had a weird odor to it...very disappointed!  I think the potatoes sitting in the crock pot for that amount of time made the consistency very gelatinous.   I was surprised to see every review so sensational as our dinner tonight was very unsavory to say the least!  Maybe it was my particular slow cooker (I cooked it on high), but I would recommend putting the potatoes in later if you are going to cook on high for the suggested period of time.

userID:
5317956
Display Name:
Lina
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing. I added 1/2 cup red wine (cabernet sauvignon), 2 tbsp worcestershire, left out celery and replaced the salt with 1/4 tsp garlic powder and a quarter tsp of cayenne pepper. I also added 1 tsp. Goya Adobo powder to the flour (I used 1/3 cup) put them in a ziplock bag and shook meat up with it until covered. I then quickly browned the meat less than a minute on each side. Combined all ingredients in crockpot and let sit in fridge overnight. Next day after 10 hours on low, I came home to the most amazing beef stew I've ever made!

text:
This was so good!! Instead of mixing the flour, salt and pepper I bought some beef stew seasoning mix and coated the meat with that. The seasoning already had worcestershire sauce in it, so I omitted my own, and I didn't have a bay leaf. When it was close to being done I put some flour in the bottom of an empty jar and added cold water. I put the lid on it and shook it up until the flour was mixed in with the water, and then poured a little in the stew and mixed it in to thicken the sauce some. I also used already peeled baby carrots...much easier. Thank you BUCHKO!!! I will be making this again!!

text:
My family and I loved this stew. I did follow Corinne's advice as I am accustomed coating and browning the beef for stews. I never have a problem with the beef being dry and this was no exception. It almost melts in your mouth but isn't soggy either. I do need to brown it in 2 separate batches. My only issue was that I am not much of a wine drinker so I had no idea what kind to buy. I had heard that you should never cook with a wine that you wouldn't drink. I ended up buying Sutter Home Sweet Red Wine, not expensive but still good especially if you're not wanting to spend a fortune on something you might not use up.

This was my first time making beef stew in a crock pot (usually make it on the stove).  I followed Corinne's suggestions and it came out GREAT!  I added about a cup extra of the beef broth because I was worried it was going to burn up cooking for so many hours, but even with this addition it still turned out nice and thick.  I let it cook on low for 11 hours and the house smelled amazing when I came home!  I'll make this again.

This stew is excellent.  I received my first-ever slow cooker for Christmas last year, and have so far been unimpressed by the recipes in the booklet that came with it.  One of the problems is that most of them aren't slow enough . . . I'm not home in 6 hours, or even 8.  At 10-12 hours, this is perfect.  I followed a couple of the reviewers' recommendations, cutting the pepper in half and browning the meat first, and it came out just right on the first try.  I'll be enjoying my second try in about an hour.  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
This is a good base recipe. The only thing I changed was I left out the celery (didn't have any) but otherwise I followed the recipe to a T (using the HIGH setting on my crockpot, I let is cook for about 5.5 hours). My boyfriend and I LOVE our food to have lots of flavor- sadly this stew was rather bland to us. I had some Zatarain's beef-flavored rice on hand that I ended up adding to our meal just for some flavor. But I gave it three stars because the TEXTURE of the beef was absolutely perfect! So tender and moist! I didn't brown it at all, as I was afraid browning it first would make it too dry. I'm glad I didn't! I'll make this again just for that alone, but I'll be adding a LOT more seasoning next time for my taste.

text:
This is a great recipe! I don't care for tomato based beef stews so this one is perfect.  I do dredge the meat in flour, salt, pepper and garlic powder and then brown prior to placing in the slow cooker.  I also cook the onions briefly and deglaze the pan with the broth before pouring the broth into the slow cooker.  I've also used this recipe to make a fantastic pot roast.  Follow the same ingredient list but replace the stew beef with a roast.  Same great taste!  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
Perfect - Just what I wanted!!!  I made a couple of changes based on what I had though..  My stew meat was frozen (less than 1.5 lb) and I just threw it in by itself for about 45 minutes before adding the flour, which I upped to 1/2 to 3/4 c.   I ended up adding about 4 cups water and a heaping T or more of "better than boullion".  I also used frozen chopped onions and way more worcestershire, salt and pepper.  TOTALLY forgot the bay leaf, and since I didn't have celery I used a few shakes of dried celery leaves.  During the last hour on high (cooked it for almost 6 hr total) I added 2 cans of diced potatoes and 1 can of whole carrots.  Came out amazing!!  Thanks for a simple recipe for this delish comfort food!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/512877.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Found this recipe while looking for a way to use a 2lb cut of beef cheek (a notoriously tough cut of meat), and it was a great base recipe that gave me some great spice/herb combinations to work with. I used a few shakes of smoked paprika, Worcestershire sauce, thyme, basil, and upped the garlic to 3-4 cloves. Didn't measure the salt or pepper, but seasoned to taste. I used two bay leaves instead of one because I added more liquid than suggested. Substituted a green bell pepper for the onion because my boyfriend hates onions, also added an extra stalk of celery and omitted the carrots (didn't have any). Slow-cooked as directed, and after the four hours on medium heat, the meat can be easily cut with a spoon. Very nice, warm, brown color and hearty taste. Thank you!

Awesome!  I usually do not like beef stew that great unless it comes from a can, but this was so good.  Even my picky hubby told me it was good.  I followed recipe almost exactly except I used garlic powder in place of garlic clove, canned taters instead of peeling and cutting them up myself and left out celery b/c not a big fan of.  My meat was still half frozen so I cooked on high for about 3 hours and then cooked for another 5 hours on low.  Sauce was thickened perfectly.  Delish!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent base recipe which can be modified easily depending on what's available in your fridge.  I like to add the following in addition to what's already listed: 2 T tomato paste, 1 can mushroom soup (and omit the beef broth), 2 cans water, 1 c mushrooms, 1 slice diced bacon, 3 extra cloves of garlic, handful of chopped fresh parsley (reserve some for the end as a garnish).  In the last 3 hours of cooking I add 1 c okra, 1 c multi-colored mini peppers, and 1 c french green beans.  This is a healthy recipe and a great way to get in your veggies... also your home will smell incredible all day!

text:
This turned out quite good. I used the flour, salt and pepper to coat the meat and browned them in a bit of oil. I sauteed the onions and garlic, then added about 1/2 cup red wine, a tsp. of dried thyme and the meat back to the pot. Added the broth, covered and simmered for about 70 minutes, then added the potatoes, carrots and about 1/2 cup of frozen corn. Simmered another 30 minutes or so. Next time I put put everything into the slowcooker after browning the meat -- I think browning gives a richer flavor.

text:
What I liked best about this recipe is that it's simple. Just throw everything into the slow cooker and let it do its thing. I did not follow the more advanced recipe, and it came out excellent. Made a few tiny changes, I used 2 cups of beef broth, and one packet of McCormick's Slow Cooker Hearty Beef Stew seasoning instead of having to add all the individual spices. Left out the bay leaf. Towards the end of cooking, I stirred in 1/4 cup of garlic mashed potato flakes, which helped thicken the sauce and give it a "kick." Delicious, will make again.

My husband and I used this recipe to try out our slow cooker for the first time. It was a great stew for a cold winter day. The only change I made was to add a little more broth (I nearly finished off the second can of broth). The flavors were wonderful, and the consistency of the meat and veggies were perfect. We cooked it on high for about 5 1/2 hours. We will definitely make this again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Probably will try again. I was afraid it might be bland, so I added half a packet of McCormick's Beef Stew seasoning and increased the worc. sauce to 1T, as suggested by some of the others. This was a mistake; the stew came out way too salty. I also substituted 4 medium to large unpeeled red potatoes (which are about half the size of regular potatoes) cut into bite-size chunks. Their waxy texture means they hold up well in slow cooking and I thought the quantity turned out pretty much just right. Also I think my stew meat (which was lean) might have been overcooked at just over nine hours. Next time I will follow the recipe as written, except for substituting red potatoes, adding an extra carrot, and checking for doneness around seven or eight hours. If it is still salty, I'll know to switch to lower sodium broth.

text:
Fantastic base. I used a little less beef, loads of carrots, celery, potatoes, and onion. I really piled on the spices and added alot more garlic. Instead of black pepper I used cayenne, our fav. I also increased the flour to 3/4 cup because I wanted to make sure it was thicker. It was perfect. I thought I had beef broth and it was chix broth so I said to heck with it and used 2 cans of chix broth and a little water (bout a cup). This turned out perfect actually. The kind of recipe you can add or remove things easily and make it your own. We will have this again after the frozen leftovers run out. ;)

Finally a crock pot recipe for beef stew that tastes like what I make on the stove!  If I could give this recipe 10 stars, I would do so!  My picky, picky DS even liked it!
  
I left out the celery as I don't like celery cooked with beef but did add an extra potato and extra onion.  I also coarsely cut the vegetables so they wouldn't over cook.  Near the last hour or so, I added 10 oz. frozen peas since I love peas in my beef stew.

Perfect crock pot beef stew recipe!

text:
My edit after making a couple more times:  After a couple of hours in the slow cooker, I ladled out about 1/2 cup of the liquid into a measuring cup, stirred in a heaping Tbsp of cornstarch, and then stirred this mixture into the stew.  I've made this recipe twice now, once following Corrine's suggestions and once following the recipe exactly (except for doubling the Worcestershire sauce).  We MUCH prefer the original recipe, both for the taste and the convenience.  If you are looking for a great TRUE BEEF STEW recipe, this is the one!!

I was disappointed with this recipe.  I used diced sirloin and omitted the celery because I was out (I can't imagine this would have saved this dish). Display Name:
TASHA156

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stew is old time classic comfort food and is delish just as written and the best part of this recipe is that you do not have to brown the beef first, that is a huge time saver and the beef turns out full of flavor and melt in your mouth tender without the fuss and extra mess of having to brown it first (I did choose to cook it on low for the longer time, I think that the long slow method rather than less time on high for things like stews makes a big difference and allows the flavors to fully develop). I like to make recipes exactly as written the first time and when I made this stew the first time it was excellent as is.  Subsequent times I have made this recipe I  added a can of diced tomatoes and used more black pepper and garlic than suggested but that is just a personal thing because I love tomatoes, black pepper and garlic.  In my opinion the sauce is thick enough as written, but if anyone wants the sauce a bit thicker, there are two simple ways to thicken the sauce, either use more flour to dredge the meat before cooking or about an hour before the end of the cooking time,  scoop out about 1/4 cup of the broth and  mix a heaping tablespoon of cornstarch into the broth until it is smooth and slowly stir the cornstarch/broth mixture back into the stew and continue cooking for the rest of the suggested time.  This is my go to beef stew recipe and I have been using it for years and everyone I have served it to loves it.

I made this stew tonight and it got a definite two thumbs up from my husband.   I used the method of flouring the meat first, browning it and then putting in the crock pot.  I added the leftover flour to the crock pot.   I also used a bit of the beef broth and 1/4 cup red wine to deglaze the pan and added it to the meat in the crock pot.  I added one additional garlic clove and used smoked paprika.  I only had one pound of the stew meat and used 2 potatoes and 4 carrots.  Towards the end of the cooking time I decided it needed a little more salt and pepper and approx. 1/2 tsp dried thyme.  I served it with freshly baked ciabatta rolls.  I will definitely make this again.  Thank you for sharing. text:
Followed the instructions as written, tempted by the ease of preparation and looking forward to a savory experience after work...what resulted was a watery, bland-tasting mess. After 10 hours on low, the meat had thoroughly cooked but since the recipe contains so little liquid added to the crockpot, not all of the potatoes or carrots cooked all the way. (Lesson learned, you need to make sure the veggies are covered in liquid too). However, had I added more liquid, I think the result would have been even MORE bland and watery. I tried to save it by picking out the par-cooked carrots and potatoes, and adding more seasonings and cornstarch to thicken up the watery consistency. I managed to get it somewhat edible, but still not great, or even passable.  If you even attempt this recipe, I suggest you follow the advice of some previous reviewers (I wish I had!) and brown the meat/saute the onion, garlic, and celery first, deglaze, and create some flavor. Also, this recipe needs more flour or some cornstarch or something so it doesn't come out so darn watery.  Stew is supposed to be thick and hearty, not watery and tasteless. Definitely could use some boullion,  seasonings, and more salt and pepper. Basically, you would need to make a whole new recipe to get this to work.

text:
There seems to be a debate over Corrine's suggestions, so lets settle it.  Any experienced cook will tell you  browning the meat before it goes into the slow cooker caramelizes the proteins and adds a depth to the flavor that you simply can’t get just by letting it boil away in the cooker. It also toasts the flour so you don’t get that gluey flour flavor in the final thickened stew.  Also, deglazing  with port, wine, or ale adds so much flavor. Deglazing is a fancy word that means to pour  cold liquid into a very hot pan to get up all the brown bits stuck to the bottom. Those brown bits are where all the flavors are.  The extra prep time is worth it.  Good basic recipe--much improved with some work.

text:
Since we need to follow Gluten Free cooking I made similar adjustments - came out great.  I used 2.5 lbs of chuck stew beef; kept the spice amounts the same; used 5 med potatoes; 8 med carrots.  used GF flour (King Arthur) approx 1 C; mixed with chicken/meat seasoning and garlic pepper - to taste - in a gallon plastic bag.  Added the beef to coat; browned in olive oil.  Added the beef broth (would increase amount to 2.5 C due to GF flour's high absorption tendency), minced garlic, paprika, Worcestershire sauce etc. to deglaze the pan beef was browned in.  Cook for approx. 2-3 min. - or enough time to loosen/scrape up all the browned beef bits.  Add to the crockpot and follow cooking times for either low or high temp cooking.

text:
This is a great base recipe for beef stew. My issue with the recipe is in the instructions.  If you makes it exactly as written, the stew will not thicken much since there will not be enough fat in the stew to make a proper roux.  I sauteed the beef and flour mixture in 2 tablespoons of olive oil and then added the onions to the mix, let them cook down a bit and added the garlic.  I then used some wine to deglaze the pan before adding the veggies, bay leaf, Worcestershire sauce and broth.  I also added a homemade stew seasoning to suit my family's tastes.  Since I don't have room for a slow cooker on my counters, I tossed the stew into a dutch oven and let it sit in the oven at 250 degrees for 8 hours.  It came out fantastic!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-02-23T16:30:02.937

I used a half bag of frozen mixed vegetables so maybe that diluted it somewhat...it was also kind of watery to me-more like a soup so I thickened it with 1/4 cup cornstarch. A decent basic recipe.

text:
This is my go to recipe for hectic days. I love that I do not need to brown the meat! I usually have it on low for 10 hrs. because of our schedule but it is always delicious.  We use less meat and more veg now to save money. I add 1 lb. stew beef, 3 lbs. potatoes, 2 lbs. carrots, 2 large onions, 5 stalks celery and 2 tsp. Worcestershire, plus a little more broth. This recipe freezes wonderfully. Thank you very much for this recipe!

None
text:
I followed this recipe almost exactly and I liked it. I added 1 1/2 cup more beef broth to it because I like my stew a little on the soupier side and added an extra potato. I also had about 4 oz of low sodium V8 in the fridge that I added to it to give it some other flavor. (My dad always used to make it with tomatoes so I felt this was proper and it gave it just a tad bit of tomato flavor. not too much though. I did not peel the potatoes either as I like the skin. This made about 6-8 man sized bowls of stew and we had a whole wheat sweet roll on the side. I've also always found that putting close to a TB of A1 steak sauce goes a long way. I didn't do that with this one, but I will next time and maybe a 1/4 ts of celery salt or some MORE celery! :)

city:

country:

text:
This is my favorite ever beef stew, and one I have made repeatedly. In fact, I've made it so often that friends will request it. I have got this down to a science: 1) I always just buy the cheapest meat at the cheapest store. This adds some more prep work, as I cover it with tenderizer and flour and then brown it, but I'm okay with that because it means I save money and the meat is still deliciously tender. 2) I like to add a few more spices (generally just some basil/oregano) 3) Also, this is the perfect place to use your left over veggies. My fave is to add zucchini or yellow squash when it's available and I got some left. I cut 'em into crescents. So good!

I loved LOVED this recipe. I made half of the portions and it all turned out amazingly. The only thing I would change is that I would add a bit more salt (then again, I used reduced sodium beef broth). I didn't brown it or anything and I felt it was perfect as is. The meat was really tender and all the flavors worked so well together. I am excited to keep using my crock pot! I added the same amount of flour and it did thicken near the end when I let it cool a bit. Simply delicious--and the smell was amazing! Fantastic with fresh baked rolls.

None
text:
The recipe is wonderful! I made this beef stew for the first time tonight, and my husband loved it. I put the stew meat in a bowl, and coated it with flour. Since we like lots of vegetables, I added two stalks of celery instead of one. Instead of garlic cloves, I added two tsp of granulated garlic. I also added 1 1/2 can beef broth, which was just enough to cover all the ingredients in the crock pot. I saved the rest of the beef broth, and I'm glad I did, as I needed more liquid for the leftovers. i just added the rest of the broth to the remaining stew. We also had a salad and corn muffins to complete the meal. I'll be making this stew over and over again! THANKS!

text:
Fantastic. I took some advice from other reviewers (but I did not brown the meat or deglaze). 

I used 1 tablespoon worcestershire sauce (instead of 1 teaspoon), used a whole can of swanson's beef broth (which is a little more than 1.5 cups), added mccormick's beef stew seasoning mix, used 2 bay leaves instead of 1, added a couple of cloves of garlic, and threw in the rest of a good bottle of red wine I had (probably 5 oz or so) that I wanted to use before it got vinegary. 

I cooked it on high for 2 hours and low for 5 hours (just because I didn't have time to wait 10 hours on this particular day). 

Served with Grandma VanDoren's bread, from this site.

Exceptionally delicious and tons of compliments. Thanks for a fabulous recipe!

I thought this was Beef Stew by Buchko not by Corrine and it's a great simple stew recipe without all those additional ingredients/steps...Thanks Buchko, this will be a new staple at our house!

put two frozen 2.5 pound pot roasts in the slow cooker this morning before work - threw all the ingredients on top (forgot the onion) and it was perfect after 7 hours on low. Awesome recipe!

text:
Excellent recipe made a couple small changes...
Decreased paprika to 1/2tsp - kids found it too spicy, sometimes I leave it out all together. Followed other suggestions of seasoned salt vs. regular salt, 2-3 garlic cloves (fresh), 2 bay leaves - I omit celery and use 2 regular potatoes and 2 sweet potatoes, I add in a packet of brown gravy mix and just eyeball the beef broth probably use about a 1/2 carton...kids love it!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is AMAZING stew! It is going in the regular rotation in our family, especially in the colder months. And who doesn't love the ease of a crock pot meal? I also followed Corinne's suggestions (thanks Corinne!) with two minor changes. I didn't have any stew seasoning packets on hand so if you find yourself in the same predicament use the spices in your cupboard. I did 2-3 shakes of each of these, garlic powder, onion powder, rosemary (one shake cuz it's not my favorite), celery seed, oregano, basil, and more generously on the paprika (smoked) since the original recipe called for it. I also added the juice of half a lemon, increased the salt to 1tsp, and used more celery because I particularly like it in a stew. Make this today! Pretty sure that you won't be disappointed.

Display Name:
