photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family really enjoyed this. They said it was the closest thing I've made called stew that was actually a down home real beef stew. Guess they don't like my twists on stew, but I'm glad they like this one. I will increase the pepper a bit next time and omit the bay leaf as they didn't like the taste (I did add a couple, so maybe it was too much.) I did mix the flour, salt and pepper with the beef and browned the beef a little first. I will also increase the broth to maybe 3-4 cups next time as the meat and veggies really soaked it up and we like at least a little broth. Also, it may just be my crock pot, but I think 7-8 hours would do the trick because after 9, everything was very cooked and the meat was falling apart.  So a few tweaks and this will be my go to Beef Stew recipe.
Review:

text:
Yum. I used a roast that I dredged in flour and browned in a skillet first.  Deglazed the pan and added that in too.  I also used a packet of McCormick beef stew seasoning.  Used red potatoes with the skin on, carrots and no celery since I didn't have it. At the end, I sauteed mushrooms in a little butter and added them to the crock pot.  Then, shredded the meat.

Display Name:
Andrea

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! I used 2 lbs. cubed sirloin beef covered with 1/2-3/4 cup of flour, 1 medium onion-sliced and slivered, 2 cups baby carrots, ~2 cups chicken broth (I didn't have beef broth), 1 large sweet potato sliced thinnned & diced, 1 cup diced peppers, ~ 1/2 cup Worcestershire sauce, ~2 tablespoons of garlic powder, 1/2-3/4 cup of apple cider vinegar, ~2 teaspoons of of dry mustard, ~2  tablespoons of yellow mustard, ~1/2-3/4 cup of brown sugar, salt and pepper dashes, I probably would have added some celery, rosemary or bay leaves if I had some (next time!)...mix it all together in the  pot, and turn on high for 4-5 hours, or let it simmer longer for ~12 hours. Strange combination of ingredients, but it works! It's really very good and low carb too! Freezes well!

text:
This was delicious & oh so easy!! I made it exactly as written. I put the flour, salt & pepper in a zip lock bag & shook the meat up in it so it was evenly coated. Then put it in the slow cooker with the veggies (left out celery cause my hubby hates it & we didn't have any) I used way more garlic than called for cause I love it & used 1 TBSP worcestershire sauce & added 1/2-1 cup of red wine....also used a full 32oz beef broth cause it seemed like it needed it. An easy great dinner cooked on low for 6 hours! Great meal with salad & fresh bread!!!

text:
I seared the beef first (seasoned with salt and pepper) then sauted a cup full of diced onions, celery and carrots in the same pan (after meat was taken out and put in the crock pot).  Added this to the  crock pot. Deglazed the pan with some of the beef stock.  Added that to the crock pot.  Then I added the rested of the ingredients to the crock pot.  (I didn't flour the meat, I added some flour at the end (mixed with some cold water - used about a teaspoon to thicken it).

userID:
3146635
Display Name:
Beth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
208
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
12/10.. Increase flour to 1/3 cup,add some paprika too,used 3 lbs beef. Put flour mixture into bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 2 tablespoons olive oil and a little butter until browned. Near the end Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker or tupperware. Mix beef broth with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker.Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning. I did it on a friday(except veg), put in fridge until sat. am(add veg and a can of tom. soup)...very tender.  30 min high and then 6 hrs. low, i added mushrooms in last hour and needed to turn the hear up to high.

text:
My favourite!  This is one we make often.  I follow the recipe for the most part, but add one tablespoon of Bisto right at the beginning.   I also omit the potatoes, and serve it on top of mashed potatoes.  This way you can add more meat and veggies if you want to, or make it in a small crock pot, which we used to have, and not worry about running out of room.  Enjoy!  Thanks for sharing Buchko!

text:
We enjoyed this.  Based on other reviewers I was going to add a package of Beef Stew seasoning and didn't have it so I jused a package of Lipton Onion soup mix instead.  I also doubled the Worcestershire, added 1/2 tsp. each of garlic powder and onion powder and added 1 tsp. of kitchen boquet.  I mixed 1 Tbsp. cornstarch and 2 Tbsp. water together and stirred into the stew before the last hour of cooking to let it thicken up.  We will make this again as it the meat was very tender and tasty.

text:
I prepared Beef Stew tonight, and it was fantastic. I did not change a thing, and my husband wanted seconds.

Update 10/5/11
This was great stew; my husband gave me thumbs up, which means it good. I did changes thing around though.  I floured the cut up meat, and brown the meat in olive oil. I placed all the vegetables in the bottom of the slow cooker and added the browned meat on top. I used 1 ½ cups of water, instead of beef broth, turn it on high and cooked it for five hrs. Oh one other thing I omitted the Worcestershire sauce.

Great recipe! I increased the garlic to 3 cloves and worcestershire to 1/4 cup.... it turned out fantastic. I would recommend using fresh carrots and not frozen... I usually use frozen carrots in recipes like this for convenience, but using fresh this time was a good move! The flavors really came out, and the dish was very homey and comforting.  The reason I gave it 4 stars and not 5 is because I would say that this is a great basic recipe, but it wasn't Extraordinary to me and didn't have something that made it over-the-top. But this is a recipe I will make again, it was very easy and pleased everyone!

I made this stew as written with the exception of dried onion instead of fresh (I hate chopping onions). Was still edible and in fact delicious so the recipe's a keeper - just be sure to add more liquid if making overnight (note: was on low for 12 hrs).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe.  My wife and kids love it!  Here's what I did differently:  Beef - Covered a 3.5 lb roast in Kosher salt for 1 hour.  Washed off salt, sprinkled with garlic powder and pepper and broiled the beef at 500 degrees for 25 minutes, then shut the oven off and left the beef in there for another 2 hours.  Unbeatable for tenderness and juicyness.  We had this for dinner.  The next day I used the remaining beef (about 2 lbs) for the stew.  I used the base recipe but doubled the ingredients and removed the celery (can't stand the stuff).  I also added mushrooms, diced tomatoes, and a packet of brown gravy.    I have done this before using pork instead of beef (prepared the same way) and I was amazed at the tenderness of the pork.  It literally melts in your mouth.  Give it a shot one of these days!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
We really enjoyed this!  It was a lot better than any beef stew we have made in the past.  One great thing about it (to us) is the recipe does not call for tomatoes!  I added one extra potato & an extra carrot for good measure. I may add an extra couple of carrots and more celery the next time as well because it was still very meaty.  (However my husband did not complain ;)  I also added a pack of McCormicks Stew seasoning and maybe 1/4-1/2 cup more of the beef broth.  We will be making this again!  ::::UPDATE:::: I made this recipe again and instead of using the McCormicks Stew Seasoning (I was out) I used a pouch of dry onion soup- big mistake the onion flavor was WAY overpowering and you couldn't taste any of the other vegetables or seasoning!  I have seen alot of the reviews for this recipe saying it has a lack of flavor and the first time I made this recipe (when I used the McCormicks) I couldn't believe that!  After trying this recipe with out it I now know that's where all the good flavor is coming from (NOT from the original recipe's seasoning).  So using the McCormicks Stew Seasoning IS A MUST!  Also I was out or worcestershire and used 2 tbs of A1 steak sauce (didn't quite like it as much but it worked in a bind).  I am only giving it 4 stars for the original recipe as written but with these changes it is definately 5 stars!

This was wonderful. I made it exactly as written (minus the celery because I can't stand it, and I used 1/4 tsp of steak sauce with a dash of soy sauce because I didn't have worcestershire sauce). I added too much liquid at the beginning because 1.5 cups just did not look like enough. I'm glad I did though because I was able to add some potato flakes about 20 minutes before we ate and the stew got thicker and creamy, which I think made this dish. We thought this was wonderful. We both had seconds and only have a bit left over - even though I made the entire recipe! Thanks!

This was the first time I ever used my slow cooker AND the first time I ever made stew!  I was very impressed with the results I got from this simple recipe!  It tasted delicious, and although I made a few subtle changes, I kept the spices the same and I was surprised at the amout of flavour I got! The only change I made was substituting some of the potato for some sweet potato... I like to use them whenever I can!  And I cooked the onions and beef a little before putting it into the slow cooker, JUST to be on the safe side!  Other than that, perfect recipe for a cold blustery day!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
What a great stew for those cold evenings!  YUM!  The meat turned out moist, tender and flavorful.  My family couldn't stay out of it!  I have already been asked to make it again!!  I chose to use a roast and shred it before serving.  I coated the meat with a mix of flour, garlic, onion powder, salt and pepper.  I browned it on all sides prior to placing in crock pot.  I used 2 cans of Swanson's beef broth and then water to cover the meat.  Along with the spices listed, I used a McCormick's Beef Stew seasoning packet as mentioned from another reviewer... WOW wonderful!  30 minutes before it was done I added a brown gravy mix packet.  It thickened up the broth nicely.  I served with toasted french bread... SUPERB!!!

I did think the recipe was really good. I did not give it a 5 star review for two reasons. The first is because I think it was a little thick and more broth could have been added. If you serve it in a bread bowl just a bit more water will do (1/2 cup). Overall it is a good recipe.

country:

text:
This was really good.  I did follow Corrine's suggestions because I like a hearty broth.  The wine definitely gave it a richer flavor than just beef broth alone.  I cooked it in the crock pot for 10 hours.  I like my broth a little thicker, so, after cooking in the crock pot all day I transferred the broth to a pot on the stove and thickened with a mixture of 1-2 tbsp cornstarch dissolved in cold water.  I then added the vegetables and beef back to the broth.  It was really wonderful and I am sure it will be even better tomorrow.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/64728.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was a pretty good recipe, but I did have to change a few things to get it closer to what I really wanted. I followed the recipe as written except for adding extra potatos, but when tasting it thought it was a little bland, so I added extra salt, pepper, and some garlic powder and onion powder as well as some lipton onion soup mix. I also thought it was a little too watery, so I took some of the potatoes out and mashed them up and stirred them back in. I thought the end product was great and so did my husband, though he would have preferred it even more thick than it was. My only gripe was the meat was so tender that it completely fell apart, but that could have been the kind of beef I used. Still tasted wonderful, anyway. I loved that this was so easy to prepare and it made the house smell fantastic all day. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Ok.  I haven't tried this yet, but I am reposting Corinne's suggestions, because so many reviewers say her changes result in a fantastic stew. I'm putting this in my recipe box and will update when I whip it up.  

 1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.

text:
I made this for our traditional Tuesday family dinner night with my brother and his family.  I made it Gluten Free by substituting equal parts of rice flour, corn starch and potato flour. The night before, I tossed the meat with the seasoned flour and then browned it skillet with some olive oil.  Then, put everything in the crockpot and placed in the fridge overnight.  Before I left for work I pulled the crock out of the fridge and set it on low for 10 hours.  When I returned home later that night the house was filled with the wonderful aroma of dinner!  I served this with corn muffins (gluten free of course).  Everyone loved it and there were no leftovers!  This is really easy and very good.

I don't think it matters either way, I'm just use to doing that way myself.

text:
Well I put this together, but made a few adjustment.... I seasoned my flour with pepper, adobo and garlic powder, and then did the same to my meat. I then tossed the meat with the flour mixture and browned in olive oil. I then used the beef broth to deglaze the pan. I added more garlic and celery then the recipe called for and added baby carrots. It was very good for a "basic" beef stew.  It definitely needed salt for our liking, but we loved it.  Next time I will definitely add more vegetables.

Very good basic recipe.  I also dredged meat in seasoned flour and quickly seared in olive oil.  I then used some of the beef stock to deglaze the pan and added to the slow cooker. Didn't use any additional flour, but I did add a can of Campbell's Golden Mushroom soup along with fresh button mushrooms. I also  used about 1/2 pkg of Birds Eye small whole frozen onions instead of chopped onion and baby carrots.  This really turned out great.  I was very pleased that the gravy wasn't real thick like some stews.

text:
This is a keeper!  First time making stew in a crock pot..I was skeptical about the broth getting thick enough.  It turned out wonderful!  I used a very large round steak (cut into chunks).  Then I doubled the beef broth and seasonings, added more flour and red wine as another reviewer suggested  and ended up with plenty of thickened broth for the amount of beef I used.  Also added the last hour frozen corn and peas.  The sweetness of the corn made a nice contrast to the spicyness of the stew.  I was also skeptical about cooking the potatoes all day....I thought they might come out mushy.  To my surprise they didn't and it was a great meal!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made today with very few variations. It tasted great! Here's what I changed:  first off I started with only 1 pound of beef since that's all I had. The spices, flour mixture and vegetables were just about perfect, but I added a little more of the potato/ celery/carrot combo because we love the veggies. And even though I only used 1 pound of meat, there was by far too little broth. So I added another cup and a half.  And I'm learning by trial and error that the crock pot I'm using cooks very quickly even on low... so it was done in 6 hours on low with tender veggies and melt in your mouth beef. Lastly, at the very end (last 10 minutes) I added an extra bit of flour/broth thickening.  It is well worth the effort and definitely a candidate for a repeat performance!

A good basic stew recipe, would be excellent for someone making stew for the first timer.  A very meaty stew. You could add 4-6 cups more of veggies and I don’t think it would be too much.

Next time I will add a few seasonings and maybe go so far as to double the flour.

text:
I made this  as written with these two.exceptions:  I added two cloves of garlic, minced.    And I put the seasoning on the meat, stirring to get all the meat covered before adding the flour.   I cooked it for about 6 hours and it turned out really good.

It is incredibly easy.  I liked having only the cutting board and a knife to clean up.  The gravy is delicious.  I'll make some noodles tomorrow and serve the leftovers that way.

Like some others said, I hate it when people drastically change the recipe and rate it with their changes.  Yes, we all like to tailor a recipe to suit our own tastes, but then don't rate the one you're using as a base!  Make your own, and submit it!

text:
It was a little weak in flavor.  I think the beef should be seared first before adding all of the ingredients.  It definitely needed more salt and Worchester sauce, and I added about a tablespoon of olive oil to smooth out the sauce.  Two cans of beef consommé in place of beef broth would have been more flavorful.  Add peas for the last 20 minutes as a flavor enhancer.

text:
I made it on the high setting and let it cook for 4 and a half hours...wasn't thrilled about it because I wanted to smell it all day but I made a time crunch decision. Either it wasn't enough time to develop the flavors, or there just wasn't enough seasoning. When I reheated it for lunch the next day I added salt, pepper, oregano, garlic powder, parsley, and thyme. It tastes like it is seasoned now, but still bland underneath it all. Pretty simple recipe but not worth the trouble, it needs quite a bit of help to get any flavor.

text:
Already made it thrice. For the most recent, I hand-diced 2.25 lb. of chuck roast, coated with flour only and lightly browned in a Dutch oven prior to adding everything else. I did omit the onion (by request) and this time I think the browning added a delightful finish. I did opt for the 6-hour high setting...was nice.

For future reference: My grocer since had chuck roast on sale for U$ 2.99/lb., so I already diced about 4.5 lb., then froze equally split in two freezer bags for the next two times I make this. This may be a serious go-to recipe for me.

text:
My family loved this! Husband said it’s the best beef stew I’ve made. This is a nice winter dish that is easy to prep. I tenderized the meat with seasoned meat tenderizer while I was prepping my vegetables. I put the meat in a ziploc bag and added the flour mixture and  a package of McCormicks Beef Stew seasoning and shook to coat. I used one can of beef broth, doubled the garlic, omitted salt & pepper bc the meat tenderizer and seasoning pack have plenty of salt. Cooked  on low for 6 hrs. Served with hot, buttery corn muffins. Delicious! TY

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I been making a stew like this for a while but has herbs in it yours doesn't like a dash of basil, marjoram, dried parsley and thyme. I skip the Bay Leaf because I always find that the bay leaf cancels the rest of the flavors of seasonings in the stew and all I taste is bay leaf. I might try it again and go in the soup and find it 15 minutes after starting cooking it and take it out. Maybe that will be better. And the other thing I do is cook the veggies separate then add them when stew is done or stew seems to taste like celery and carrots than the beef flavor that I want. Yours tastes very good the way it is, not trying to say it doesn't. Just telling my experiences with other stews I made. Thanks for the recipe!

userID:
3420502
Display Name:
Tess

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is probably perfect as written, but I made a few minor changes and the family (3 adults and a 10 y.o.) said it was the best beef stew ever!  
I had a packet of McCormick's Slow Cookers Hearty Beef Stew mix on hand and stirred that into the beef broth before adding it to the crockpot.  I also poured in a small (8 oz.) can of  tomato sauce and a splash of red wine.  The tomato sauce blends in and just compliments the flavor.  Stepson doesn't like the texture of onions and celery, so I used a half cup of diced onions and they cooked down, just adding flavor.  I threw in 2 stalks of celery, broken in half for the stock, and removed them at the end. The stew came out nice and thick, the way they like it. 

No need to brown the meat first! The beef was tender and falling apart the way it should (I used small cuts of round).  This recipe is so easy and the cleanup is a cinch.  Spraying the crockpot first with Pam makes it super easy to clean afterwards.

...BTW - some reviewers mentioned that they don't like reviews that include recipe changes. But the review box asks you to write about the changes you made, and I love this site for the recipes and also for the reviewers' tweaks!

text:
This was good, not great and I'm talking about the smell and the flavor. I used only the ingredients and spices that the recipe asked for. I didn't add others or delete any. It had a weird smell while cooking and the taste took some acquiring. It didn't have the same taste that I am used to in a stew but after a few bites, I liked it. I used a 3 lb piece of round roast and cut it into cubes. 2 lbs just seem like enough. I didn't change any of the ingredients but I did double the quantity for gravy ingredients as we like to make dumplings on top and they soak up a lot of the liquid. Doubling the gravy ingredients gave it just the right amount. The meat was soooo tender. I will make this again but I will try to add other spices to give it that more classic stew flavor that I'm used to.

I am not a cook.  I need to have detailed instructions for anything that I cook.  I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out just great.  Nice tasty, thick gravy with tender beef with just the right spices. I set my slow cooker to High and it was done in four hours with the vegetables done to just the right texture.  Next time, I will try the "low" setting on my slow cooker, because it began to stick to the bottom as it reached 4 hours on "high". It was a hit with my wife so I will be making again.....soon I hope.

I have made this recipe quite a few times and I've loved it each time. I use it every time I make beef stew! We love it so much, I've had guests request it. This recipe has a strong flavor and it's nice and thick, just as beef stew should be. :) The vegetables are always perfectly soft and the meat is exquisitely tender. I haven't needed to change anything when making this recipe, I highly recommend it and I have actually linked some of my friends to it. :) Thanks so much for sharing this!

I'd love a way to turn it into a stove top recipe, that way I can use it for leftover roast, haha.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you BUCHKO for posting this recipe! Now I can save it in my favorites and not worry about losing it. This beef stew is a crock pot classic and therefore the simplicity of this recipe should not be altered in my opinion. Sure, one can take an extra 30 minutes to brown the meat and then clean your stovetop, counters and more dishes.....but then you're missing the whole point of enjoying an easy to prepare and delicious meal! As is, I am happy to rate this recipe a 4 due to the tasty results with such little work. I like to prep everything the night before and throw it together in the morning, go on with my life and not worry about what's for dinner. The saying work smarter, not harder comes to mind. I'm a well seasoned cook and enjoy preparing complex and elaborate meals for my family, when I'm in the mood to spend hours in the kitchen. But when I'm not, I reach for my trusty crock pot and search for the simplest recipes that taste like I've been in my kitchen all day. And this recipe exceeds expectations every single time. I've made it as written and then tweaked it many times and it's always delivered great results. You may find that you need to season it to your tastes. Play around with some herbs or a spoonful of tomato paste to create depth. But save yourself the hassle and don't worry about searing your meat.

text:
This is excellent.. I made it last night and it turned out great. I made the following changes:
* In bowl, mixed flour, salt and pepper. Added beef chunks and coated. Added to crockpot. 
* Added chopped vegetables to crockpot. 
* I didn't have canned/boxed beef broth so used beef bouillon granules mixed with water. I stirred in paprika and Worchestershire Sauce. Pour over vegetables and stir. 
* Just before the stew was done I added frozen peas.

text:
This is a great base recipe. I made it pretty consistent to the directions, just without actually measuring anything because I tend to eyeball/cook to my own taste unless I'm baking. With that said, I think this stew could have been better with some additions. Next time I will definitely add a half a bag or so of frozen peas, and might even go for mushrooms. I'd also likely throw in the onions and/or celery a bit later down the line - I prefer my onions cooked but not totally disintegrated. As is the recipe earned the seal of approval from my boyfriend and his work friend - and I've taken it to work several times and enjoyed my lunch each day. Great job!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was tasty and easy to make.  A very basic beef stew.  Probably why it is so popular.  Leaves a lot of room to adjust to personal taste.  The gravy was a bit grainy, perhaps it was due to the whole wheat flour I used.  Taste and texture was fine.    I also overcooked it.  I have a new crockpot and still getting used to the settings.  Mine was done in 3 hours on high.

Suggestions for my taste:
Brown the beef first along with the flour. 
Deglaze the pan with some 1/2 cup of red wine and 8 ounces of mushrooms of your choice.   

A bit more broth can be added near the end as needed.   Mine was a bit dry per the recipe but I may have added more potatos than usual.

adjust any ingredient as needed after you put everything in crock.   

I like to make the recipe exactly as listed the first time then make notes.   If you like it a bit more complex toss in some herb de provence or whatever else you like.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I copied the other reviewers changes and it was excellent. Made it 2 times in one week based on family demand! SUPERB beef stew! I took the great base recipe, and tweaked it with a compilation of reviewer recommendations. The end result is a winner, to be sure. Here is what I did (and I won't change a thing the next time I make it): 1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth (I used Swanson's Certified Organic in aseptic carton) with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning. Your home will smell wonderful all day, and your meal will be a savory feast! I served the stew in bowls, accompanied by slices of fresh, crusty bread.

text:
This was an amazing beef stew.   The spices were perfect and the smell was heavenly.  The only thing I did differently was after shaking the beef in the flour mixture in a Ziploc bag, I added 1/4 more cup of flour to the bag along with the rest of the spices and the garlic and beef broth and mixed them together in the bag and then poured over everything in the slow cooker.  Much easier.  I also placed the potatoes, veggies etc on the bottom of the slow cooker to cook for a while first before stirring together.  It makes a great gravy for the stew too.

None
text:
There is a lot going on here that simply didn't work, and it was pretty obvious that it wasn't going to once I started into it. Needs salt in the broth as well as in the flour, needs 3x as much broth than called for, and I used less beef (1.3 lbs) and more veggies. I cut back on flour by half a cup as well. Also 12 hours is WAY too long. I cooked for 10 and even then it was so cooked down that after having to add more salt and other spices to give it any kind of flavor, and stirring a few times, it was basically meat paste. The end result tasted good, but it looked nothing like the photo. 1 star because without significant modifications, this is likely borderline inedible.

Display Name:
Casablancaise
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7503916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a rich, comforting stew that is very good, even without the meat browning that many reviewers are recommending. My only change was to up the veggies , by adding couple more carrots, 1 more stalk of celery and small package of mushrooms. But I should have known better, by adding more veggies I made the sauce/gravy on the runny side ( for the less experienced cooks, vegetables release water during cooking ). I had 2 options to fix this, either adding a slurry to the stew or ladle the sauce in a saucepan and reduce it on the stove. I chose to reduce the sauce to intensify the beefy flavor.
I will still add more vegetable next time, but will cut down the broth to 1 cup.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great start to a fabulous beef stew! I used the basics from this recipe only pumped up the veggies, my family likes a lot of veggies. I seasoned and floured the beef then browned it well in a sauté pan before adding it to the slow cooker with the carrots and potatoes. In the sauté pan add the garlic, celery, onion and minced mushrooms (adds to the beefy flavor), stir to soften then add 1 packet Beef Stew Mix, 1/2 cp red wine & Worcestershire sauce to deglaze pan, add to slow cooker with 3-4 cps beef broth & cover. Serve with a crusty bread. Best stew ever!

I've made this stew a number of times and I always precooked the meat. I thought it would be better if I browned the meat before throwing it together. I was wrong. It tastes better following the recipe exactly as written. I cooked it on low for 10 hours and it may be my slow cooker but it was a bit dry so next time I will either adjust my cooking time or add a bit of extra broth. This is so simple to make and save yourself the time and mess,  I recommend you don't change the recipe at all.

Display Name:
EXPLORER5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this at least 2 dozen times. First time I followed the recipe. Then I made a few very minor changes. Mix flour and spices in plastic bag. Instead of regular paprika I use 1 teaspoon smoked paprika and 1 teaspoon hot Hungarian paprika. Add beef to bag and shake to coat. Leave beef in bag while prepping veggies. When veggies are prepped shake bag once more. Dump beef in crockpot. Toss in veggies and additional ingredients. Stir once and cook on high for 2 hrs. After 2 hrs stir and continue cooking on low. Usually 6-7 hrs. I normally serve with small tossed green salad and hunks of toasted garlic bread. Have a pot cooking right now and house smells great.

This recipe is great!  Bought a power pressure cooker was in a hurry to try a recipe and this came out great.  I doubled paprika, garlic and worcheshire, added more potatoes and parsnips.  Everyone loves it.  Then I tried swapping chicken for beef and chicken broth for the beef broth,everything else basically the same, that came out fabulous to, actually Even better.  My daughter keeps asking for recipe chicken version and my husband is eating it out of the pot before its served - I made it today for tomoro and I had to hide the whole pot or he would eat it in the middle of the nite---never any leftovers.  This recipe is especially good if your on a budget and you just need to scrounge stuff from the fridge for a meal.  BTW dont like the power pressure cooker, probably a better one out there but i own it now so I have to use it, does it in 30 minutes when it works. and BTW I made it exactly before I tweaked anything, great!  Now I just tweak according to what meat I have on hand.

text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe exactly and I thought it was regular old beef stew.  Today I decided throw some other stuff in there for some more flavor. Whatever I had in the house. No browning, but I added onion powder to the flour, then added some red wine in with the broth, 2 fresh bay leaves and some added salt and pepper. I had a parsnip and some fresh parsley in the house and threw those in, and then added some sciracha on a whim. It was so much more flavorful! Served it over whole wheat egg noodles. A terrific dinner.

text:
I made this recipe pretty much as it was written.  I liked that I didn't have to brown the meat and camarlize the onions before adding to the crockpot.  I considered it, but glad I didn't.   The meat had pretty good flavor and was moist and I didn't have to dirty more dishes or take more time to prep. The only things I did differently was add the paprika to the flour/salt/pepper and add some thyme.   Next time,  I will add a little more salt and pepper, maybe a full tsp, a little more worchestershire sauce plus some tomato paste.

Excellent and easy.  I never like the way fresh potatoes come out in beef stew in the slow cooker. text:
This is a great, simple recipe that you can add to or modify according to your tastes. I loved that I could throw it all in together and let it cook all day. I was a bit leery that the beef would turn out dry but it was very tender and moist - I cut up a blade steak which may have had more marbled fat than the usual stewing beef. I added more celery as I like it, and shook up the flour with the broth and 1T Worchestershire, otherwise I stuck to the recipe, stirring every couple of hours. Even my husband, who usually grumbles if I make stew loved this.

userID:
2197004
Display Name:
kaz
isPro:

10

102

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/85418.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I broke one of my big rules ..... I "enhanced' this recipe based on a number of reviews before making it...... but, in my defense .... every change made sense ...... including: swapping reg. salt for seasoned; increasing flour to 1/3 C & putting the seasoned flour in a bag with the meat to coat then sautéing the beef in EVOO until browned. I added the onion then put it in the slow cooker. Next I mixed the beef broth with the worchestershire sauce & 1/2 C red wine to deglaze the browning pan. added that to the beef and ran it on "high" for 2 hours.
Then I cut up and added the potatoes & onions, added 2 cloves of garlic, 2 bay leaves, the remaining ingredients, a packet of McCormicks Beef Stew Seasoning, a C of water and dropped the temp to "low" for the next 4 hours ..... oh and the paprika I used was Hot Hungarian.
It was AWESOME. A slight "bite in the back of the throat, TENDER TENDER beef, thick gravy, tender veggies, and a great meal. I served it with crusty French bread ........... a REALLY good meal .... TRY IT!!!
UPDATE: It's even better the next day!!!

text:
I made the recipe exactly as written, and while it smelled amazing while it was cooking, it turned out really bland. It needed a lot of salt and pepper to make it palatable. I really want to avoid sauteing the meat (what's the point of using a slow cooker if you're going to fry your food first?), but next time I will absolutely try adding some rosemary or some other spices to try and perk up the flavor. I'd also agree with some others that more veggies are needed; the beef to veggie ratio was pretty lopsided.

text:
Pretty much standard and how I do it except for two things. One, you need to brown the meat. It will NOT make it dry but will actually help keep the juices inside and avoid any possible food borne illnesses. And secondly, I am guessing the author did not mean to write one STALK of celery. This is WAY too much. I am guessing he meant one RIB of celery. I use 2 or three. Bon Apetit! Chef Cosmo

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed this recipe to a T. Good, but it was missing something - and meat seemed rather chewy (even on low, 12 hours). So, I tweaked...

Cheated. Used McCormick beef stew seasoning packet for base, as well as 2 cans of beef broth. Prior to placing in crock pot, floured beef > browned. HATE celery - axed it. Left potato, onion and "baby" carrots (1 full bag instead of having to slice). And now, for the "secret ingredient" (or so my husband has referred to it as) - PARSNIPS! While similar to carrot, imo, they're spicier and have a mild sweetness, which takes away from the dish being too savory. Overall, adds a different kick/bite.

Meat was "As tender as a maiden's prayer", and cooked 4 on high,  2 on low.

text:
Excellent base stew.  I'm incapable of not messing with the basic recipe, so I did make some changes based on things I know we like.  I added an extra garlic clove, replaced 1/2 cup of the broth with red wine, and left out the celery (because I didn't have any).  Cooked on High for 4 hours and was pleased with the results. 4 stars because for my personal taste, it would have been lacking just a bit of extra flavor without the changes that I could tell I wanted to make.  Will definitely keep this one around as a basic launching point for future stew days.

It didn't meet the thick, hearty stew criteria. It was more watery and I felt it was more like a glorified pot roast with beef cubes instead of a hunk of meat. The texture of meat, veggies, potatoes all came out really tender without being mushy but I had my crock pot on high heat for about 4 hours and then turned to low heat for the last 2 hours, because everything was chopped smaller than what I use to make a pot roast. My whole family felt it tasted bland. My husband broke out the ketchup and I added horseradish!

First, I followed the recipe pretty much exactly. Came out great. Some of these reviews are ridiculous by lowering the stars because they added 20 new ingredients. This is a crock pot recipe, so I think reviewers should take into consideration that this is a convenient recipe to throw in a crock pot and disappear for a while. Naturally, potatoes in a crock pot will get a little mushy cooking for 5-10 hours. 

I used a brisket and the meat fell apart!! Also, my slow cooker is the Kitchen Ninja. I would make this recipe again.

text:
This was my first time making beef stew and it
turned out really good.Since I like tomatoes and
barley in beef stew,I added both.One half cup of pearled barley and one 28oz. can of stewed tomatoes,diced and not drained.I added more broth(1 QT instead 1 1/2 cups) because I knew
the barley would require more liquid.I also added 1 T. of sugar.This is an easy,delicious slow cooker recipe and I will definitely be making it again.I realize there are other recipes that already include barley and
tomatoes, but this one looked so simple and good that I decided to just
add to it.Everyone loved it!

text:
The base is great. Very tasty! WAY too much meat, though. I decreased the meat to 1.3 lbs. and kinda eyeballed the vegetables--probably a little more than this recipe calls for. Next time I will add more beef broth and more vegetables. Two pounds of beef is just overpowering. I did coat the beef in a ziplock bag, but I didn't brown it before putting it in the slow cooker. I also put all the vegetables, especially the potatoes, on the bottom of the slow cooker. The meat cooked just fine sitting on top!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A delicious stew recipe exactly as it is.  I added a little garlic salt to my bowl because of preference (but I wouldn't be against not having added it), and my boyfriend ate it with nothing added, so it all depends on the person's taste.  The watery juice threw me off at first, but it thickened up after it had the chance to sit for a few minutes.  Because of time, but because I prefer slow-cooker recipes cooked on low, I cooked it for 5.5 hours on low, then 2 hours on high (about halved both cooking times), and it turned out perfectly.  I'm saving this recipe to make again.

I was impressed by the simplicity and ease of this recipe... I was doubtful, but this is a classic beef stew.  I left out the flour due to a gluten allergy, so the gravy was thin, but I just added 1 tsp. arrowroot starch to give it some body.  I also added more salt at the end, just to my taste.  This made a fantastic breakfast with a fried egg on top.  Thank you, I'm done looking for beef stew recipes!

text:
This was my first attempt at cooking crock pot stew (or stew of any kind for that matter), since I am a beginner cook I followed the recipe to a T (since I didn't have any idea what I was doing in the first place). I am a VERY picky eater and I found the recipe delicious as is. I cooked on HIGH for 5 hours and let set for 30 minutes. The only thing I would do differently is probably let it cook for an hour first before adding the potatoes next time as I like my potatoes more firm than mushy . As I become a more experienced cook I may play around with adding different seasonings simply because I prefer my food spicy.  But again, I want to emphasize that the recipe is pretty good as is and I agree with what others have recommended...TRY IT FIRST BEFORE tweaking.

country:

text:
I made this with Corinne's suggestions and was very pleased.  My ingredients weren't submerged in the beginning, so I added more beef broth.  As the beef cooked and let out water, I ended up with a pretty watery stew.  Not to worry: I added an extra half tblsp of flour and simmered on high for a few minutes with the lid off the crockpot.  It turned out excellent.

I know that some of you don't want to brown your meat before putting it in the crockpot, but it takes an extra ten minutes (most of which is spent staring at your delicous beef) and is so worth it.  My stew literally melted in my mouth.  I kind of want to make it again before the week is over.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh. My. Goodness!  This is THE best crock pot beef stew EVER.  I followed Corinne's additions from her October 10, 2006 post and you will absolutely never have to use another recipe again for beef stew.  

It's not, however, a dish I'd try to throw together before walking out the door in the morning - a little pre-prep would be needed if you're planning to do that.  But I browned the beef and got everything into the crock pot within about 40-minutes from start to finish (including cleaning veggies and cutting them up)  I didn't think 40-minutes was all that bad.  In the original recipe you don't have to brown the beef and I'll probably try that the next time just to see if there's a difference in taste - but this recipe with Corinne's corrections is absolutely guest-ready ... including those who knit-pick at what you serve (we all have 'those' people in our families)  I'd give this six stars if I could.

I followed the recipe and directions as written except used a packet of onion soup mixed in 1 1/2 cups water in place of the beef broth. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried this recipe twice now. First time cooking on high heat, second time on low heat. The first time, the meat was pretty tough. The second time, the potatoes were practically raw. Both times, the broth was super thin and had weird bits of brown stuff floating around in it. Not very appetizing. To soften up the raw potatoes in my second try, I boiled the soup for about 30 minutes after it had cooked for 12 hours on low heat. This thickened the broth and softened the potatoes, and actually made the soup much better. However, given my woes of making the stew, I will not use this recipe again!

Display Name:
mikeyo
isPro:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very bland and boring stew when made following the recipe.  First there was not enough beef broth , this needs to be at least doubled.  I made this per the recipe and was disappointed.  Not bad tasting, just very plain and bland.  Let it sit in the fridge for two days, then heated it up but added 16 oz. of beef broth, 3 shakes of garlic powder, 5 shakes of cayenne pepper, 3 shakes of paprika and 4 grinds of sea salt.  It had some flavor at last.  My wife always tells me to not follow the recipes but make them my own, and this was an excellent example of that.    You may have noticed, I don't cook with "precise" measurements, and for good reason, personal taste.  This stew can be made much better.  And the second go round in our was just that, much better.

A wonderful mouth watering, winter rib sticking recipe.  I'm glad I read Corinne's review before I made this because she had some excellent recommendations.  I also saluted the beef and onions and deglazed the pan with red wine.  I seasoned the beef with a red meat seasoning before saluting and thickened the liquid with corn starch.  Beyond that, cooking everything on low for 8 hours was sufficient for me.  This dish is amazing!  Excellent recipe!

Thanks for the keeper recipe!!!

text:
I can't recommend this. I followed the recipe without any changes and the meat is so dry and has a near sandy texture to it. If you're headstrong on trying this you need to use chuck meat because the cubed stuff marked "stew beef" on the supermarket isn't going to give you predictable results. I think I'm going to let it cool off completely and then refrigerate it overnight so the meat pulls some moisture back into it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed this with the one change as suggested by others - I seared the beef (after shaking in the flour, salt, pepper and garlic powder) and then added the chopped onions (I did this in two batches) and added to the slow cooker.  Kept everything else the same - and cooked for 6 hours on high.  It was delicious - just the right thickness (and I was worried as it didn't look to be enough liquid when I started out).  Have subsequently frozen a batch of meat, that has been seasoned and seared in order to quickly put this together another time - just have to add the rest of the veggies, broth and W. sauce!  A keeper!

I found the stew a bit bland, and felt it needed quite a bit more liquid. Then it was yummy (worth 4 or 5 stars), served with crusty bread.

text:
A good basic beef stew recipe. I made a few changes to it to make it to my taste. I just add the meat and flour into the slow cooker without sauteing it. I don't add celery (just don't like it). Then I also add a can of Hunt's petite diced tomatoes. I then add a can of corn at the end just to heat it (depending on the mood, it's either a small or a large can). Comes out delicious with these changes/additions.

Okay so I made this last night at 5pmm and let it cook all the way until today at 6 pm on low. I put a slow cooker slip in my croc pot so there was no clean up! You can buy them at stop and shop. I didn't tweak this recipe much instead of chopping up onions I peeled the onion and put it right in the stew, my family doesn't like onion just the flavor. When the stew was done I took it out. I added the mccormick stew seasoning. This stew was AWESOME esp.if youu use golden gourmet baby potatoes! DELISH. I recommend this to anyone and let it cook for a long time trust me its worth the wait. Put some pillsbury flakey biscuits with it and you'll be all set !!

text:
Excellent base recipe- I followed Corrine's review almost exactly on this with just a few differences.  I used 3 cloves of garlic, and half of a big Walla Walla sweet onion.  I also used 2-14 oz cans of beef broth instead of just 1.5 cups, there was SO little liquid in the pot that the dry seasoning was just sitting on top of the veggies.  It still thickened up nicely.  I let it simmer for about 11 hours and it was delicious!  I only cook for two people so I'll be putting the rest in the freezer for another meal.

I followed the instructions in the review by Corinne on 10/10/06 and the stew turned out wonderful!  A couple of hints of my own:  If you have beef broth left over save it to thin the stew if needed but don't use too much.  Serve the stew the day after making it. We loved it! House smelled amazing for long time and couldn't wait to eat this one! I read reviews and made some changes, but very minor ones: 1. I used cubes and water instead of broth (this is what I had) 2. I added 1/2 cup of red wine but I did not brown the meat 2. text:
I am newly retired and just started cooking. I joke with friends and say I am like a new bride learning to cook. This was my first time using a crock-pot. With the help of this recipe, it could not have been more simple. The best part is that the resulting stew was outstanding. My wife came home from work, and there it was. I also had skillet corn from another Allrecipes recipe, and a nice big salad. MMMMM. Heck, I even took the leftovers over to the in-laws, so I got some got some good points there. For anyone who wants to cook an amazing meal that is easy, I strongly recommend this one.

text:
This was terrific. Made it last night, using most of the "Corinne" suggestions.  It was the best beef stew I've ever made.  In fact, my husband said it was the best beef stew he's ever eaten.  As I said, I followed all of Corinne's suggestions, except instead of 1/2 c wine, I used 3/4 c. Boddington's Pub Ale.  I also used new red potatoes, halved.  It was phenomenal.  Thanks for a great recipe that I will be using again and again!  With the changes, it certainly merits 5 stars!

text:
Good basic recipe but  definitely needed tweaking. I browned the beef very well before transferring to a crock pot. I deglazed saute pan with the beef broth, 1/2 cup good red wine and some water. Also threw in 2-3 medium minced shittake mushrooms (dried is better), and a packet of lipton onion soup. Let it simmer for 6-7 hours and served with mashed potatoes. There was NO leftovers!

text:
I thought this was tasty.  I made mostly as is.  I set up the night before, covered my slow cooker with plastic wrap, and kept in the fridge overnight.  I didn't have any beef broth so I threw 3 boullion cubes and 1.5 cups of water into the pot.  Used ~2 tbsp of Worcheshire sauce.  I think that the cooking temps need to be adjusted.  I had it on high and when I came back 6 hours later most of the liquid had evaporated out so I needed to add another 0.5 cup of water to it, and continued to heat on warm setting until ready for dinner.  I think next time I'm going to just cook on low for about 8 to 9 hours.

text:
Yummy!!! I used a large gallon ziploc bag to coat the beef with the flour mixture. I love celery, so one stalk wasn't enough for me. I used about 2 1/2 stalks total. The only other change I made was using Better Than Bouillon Beef mixed with water, instead of broth (I never seem to have broth on hand). I admit I was nervous about not browning the beef first, but I was feeling lazy and followed the recipe instructions because I didn't want to have another dirty dish. It was AWESOME!!! The meat was so tender and the stew was delicious! I will be making this again for sure!

country:
None
text:
YUM!  This is comfort food at its best!  I made a few changes and additions.  I used only one pound of stew meat.  Anymore would be too much.  My additions were to use 1/3 C Flour, two cloves of garlic, two bay leaves, 1/2 C Red Wine, 3 stalks of celery, and chopped mushrooms.  I used another reviewers suggestion to put the flour, salt, pepper, and beef in a zip lock to coat them meat.  Then browned the beef in a skillet, then add the onions until soft.  Then poured in the liquids and cooked on med for 5-7 mins.  Combined everything in crock pot and cooked on HIGH for 4 hours.  So GOOD!!

text:
This was great! I have to say that beef stew has been a staple with me, I make it quite often during the fall and winter. I have always followed my Mom's lead and browned the beef before hand. This time I didn't. I pretty much followed the recipe exact, except added more carrots, no celery or bay leaf, a bit of extra seasoning and used 3 lbs of beef. I like this so much better than the way I have always done it! Plus, it makes it much healthier when you don't pre-cook the meat in any kind of oil. It thickened up nicely. I am very, very happy with this!

text:
We loved this dish overall. I was quite distressed because I followed the 10-12 cooking hour suggestion even though I added an extra cup of water thinking 10-12 hours needed more water not like the recipe suggested.  I left the slow cooker unattended (that is the beauty of slow cookers...) and when I came back to check on it around hour 7 must of the meat was not in cubes but kind of melted in to the dish.   The taste was fabulous and easy to make but beware of the time or add more water and adjust the seasonings to the dish.  I am pretty experienced cooking  with  slow cookers. I will make this recipe again like suggested but only 6 hours in low.  That is the reason I will give it 4 rather than 5 stars

Turned out excellent, got lots of good reviews. Put meat in slow cooker, sprinkled flour, seasoned salt, pepper on it, mixed it up.  Added vegetables (including frozen corn) and a packet of beef stew seasoning.  3 cups of beef stock 1/2 cup red wine, 1T worcesershire. About 9 to 9.5 hrs on low and it was chow time, served with thick slices of crusty bread.

This is a wonderful recipe. I would suggestion would be to cook this recipe as written, for the first try. It's that good. One serving suggestion, I always add peas to my stew, by adding  room temperature frozen peas just prior to serving. They keep that fresh color that way. If some people in your family don't like peas, just put them in the indvidual bowl and stir, before serving.

I made this recipe for the first time the other day, and I must say it turned out awesome! My fiance loved it! The only thing that I really changed was that I added more beef broth than the recipe called for. I added enough so that all the ingredients were covered. I put in on my crock pot's 8 hour setting and let it go all day. When it was almost done, I added some corn starch to thicken it up a bit and it turned out perfect! The meet was so tender that it was falling apart! I will continue to make this stew for years to come! Great recipe!

The great thing about stews, especially in the crock pot, is that you can fiddle around with the ingredients and throw in what you like. Since I did not have all of the ingredients this recipe called for on-hand, my review is based mostly on the cooking technique. text:
This was a very good stew. It was my first time making stew but my husband, who love stew and grew up on that kind of thing, thought it was great. I've never been a big stew fan but I really liked it.  I gave it four stars because my final product, after taste testing the original which my husband still really liked, I added the brown gravy packet for extra thickness and flavor. Next time I might try a little wine for another layer of flavor like another reviewer suggested.  Other posters suggested browning the meat first and sauteing the onions etc. but it's not necessary.  By itself it is a great base and very easy and good in and of itself.

text:
Absolutely delicious! This was my first attempt at any kind of stew, or any kind of crock pot recipe, but I followed the recipe as close as I could (I had to trim the ingredients down a bit as I have a small crock pot). I let it stew for a little more than 12 hours and as soon as I came home the most delicious aroma greeted my senses. When I removed the lid it smelled faintly of beef teriyaki but man oh man, this is seriously a delicious stew! Very nice and hearty, everything nice and tender. My boyfriend loves it and I think even our cat wants some. Will definitely be making it again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like many people here I rate this one only four stars as it really does have to be tweaked to be more than basic.  That said, on its own it's a terrific option for low-budget meals that go far--I filled my seven quart crock-pot before leaving for work and came home to a beautiful, thick stew that hadn't reduced a whole lot in volume.    I did not brown the meat before putting it in (I don't have much time in the mornings before work); I did add more paprika, more black pepper, more garlic, and much more salt than called-for; as well I added some basil and some white wine.  The meat is perfectly cooked, melt-in-your-mouth tender, and the vegetables are tasty and cooked but not mushy.    As has been noted in previous reviews, even on low this stew needs only about 8-9 hours in the crock pot.  Yum!

text:
This stew only gets a four because I used many of the tweaks that other reviewers suggested. But it still made my husband say "Wow!" (not an easy thing to do). I browned the beef first (because that's just the way I make stew) and deglazed the pan with the broth. I added the packet of stew seasoning, more broth and more garlic per our tastes. In the end it might've  been a bit too much broth because it had to be thickened with corn starch. Still tasted good though. Served it with a loaf of crusty sourdough and it was the perfect meal!

Wonderful stew ! Very tasty...very easy : ) Tried several stew recipes and this is the first my husband and I both truly enjoyed . My only suggestion based strictly on personal taste would be to increase the veggies as we found it was a little too meaty . I did add a stew seasoning packet and increase the garlic the second time I made it just to compare . city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all, thanks BUCHKO for the posting.  I enjoyed the outcome, but my guests & DH were thrilled with the results.  Here's what I did differently: used only 2 Tbsp. flour, no additional salt (didn't think it would need it, and it didn't), used 14.5oz. can beef broth, added 15oz. can diced tomatoes w/ their juice, added 8oz. can tomato sauce (we like a tomato based stew), added a 15oz. can drained Italian style green beans, 15oz. can drained great northern beans, 1 c. frozen baby lima beans & 1 c. frozen sweet corn.  The additional beans and corn I added during the last 45 mins. of cooking time.  I would probably make it next time with either chicken broth or water instead of beef broth for myself, as I don't like that rich of a beef flavor (former vegetarian).  It was very well received by my company though.  I would definitely make again.

I subsituted one can of cream of chicken for cream of mushroom w/roasted garlic, added a packet beef onion dried soup mix, added a can of low fat/low sodium beef broth, a box of frozen peas and carrots, and served with brown rice.  Yum-o!

text:
Excellent stick to your ribs beef stew.  No need to pre-cook the meat as some have suggested.  It turns out perfectly delicious without.  I followed the directions exactly with the exception of just mixing together enough flour with the meat (I didn't measure it).  I also added tomato juice because we prefer a tomato based stew.  Will make this again.

text:
Following a few recommendations, I increased the flour to 1/3 C and also added a 1/2 C wine.  I wasn't blown away by the taste and maybe that had to do with the 1/2 Tspn of salt. I ended up adding extra to improve the taste.  I also think next time, I will eliminate the wine and go for a tomato paste addition.  But I definitely stayed away from browning meat as the slow cooker is made to keep things easy and the meat turned out perfect.

text:
I couldn't access my old hard drive and was making my recipe from memory and checked on-line to see if I forgot anythin obvious. Found this recipe which is very similiar to mine, and yep, forgot the bay leaves. I follow very closely the recommended modifications. I brown the meat in olive oil. I add about 1/3-1/2 cup wine. I triple the worchestire sauce to 3 tbsp, add fresh green beans, and I add 1 tbsp basil, and sometimes a sweet hot sauce called tiger sauce to deepen the flavor. 1- 2 tbsp. When it is within an hour or so of done I make a roux with butter and flour to do any thickening up I desire. Very hearty and yummy! My recipe is so close I imagine I likely got it from here in the first place.

text:
This is a great recipe.  Regarding Corrine's suggestions, I just thought that was way too much work.  I use a slow cooker so I can do things fast and I did not want to invest that much time.  Having said that, I did flour the meat and saute it, but then I just dumped everything in the slow cooker as the recipe said.  I added 1/2 cup red wine, thyme, and rosemary, and I used HOT paprika.  It really was delicious.  I think next time I will use a can of golden mushroom soup too.  I might have liked a little more juice.  Even with the added spice, my 2 year old twins really liked it.

userID:

Display Name:
MOOCHIA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've always been so-so about beef stew, but this is really wonderful WITH the alterations suggested in previous posts, namely: using seasoning salt in with the flour for dredging, increasing the garlic (3 cloves for me), and adding wine and 1 T. Worcestershire sauce to the beef broth.  I also have to give a shout out to the McCormick stew seasoning.  I usually avoid packaged seasoning mixes, but here it is essential and really makes for a tasty stew.  I added another onion, coarsly chopped, and added more potatoes (Yukon golds and fingerlings work great, plus no need to peel them).  Finally, I put the veggies in first with the meat on top since they are a little slower to cook and benefit from getting more of the heat.  This is the only crockpot stew I've ever made that did NOT have to be thickened before serving; the consistency was perfect after eight hours.  Truly a keeper!

text:
I'm rating this low because of the fact that there are hardly any veggies, I thought I was reading the 2 lbs. of meat wrong but I went ahead and made it the way the recipe read.  It turned out to be almost all beef with a tiny smattering of vegetables.  I've never seen beef stew made that way, and the picture by the way is not representational.  When you scoop a bowl of this stew, you will find 99% meat and a couple pieces of carrot/potoatoe.  A few easy modifications, such as cut the meat in half, would make all the difference.  The flavor itself was good and I like how simple the recipe is.  Just way too much beef.

text:
Wowww.. this is good stuff.  I followed Corrines suggestions such as searing the beef and glazing the pan with the broth, onions, and garlic.  I didn't have fresh garlic as usual so I just used the minced garlic in a jar, 2 tsps. Used 4 small red potatoes, quartered. This had the perfect flavor.. everyone loved it.  I cooked it on low for 6 hours then on high for almost two hours.  That turned out to be just right.   Does not need any "stew seasoning packet" or onion soup mix. Definitely recommend this recipe.  THANK YOU

text:
I wanted to do a second review, but the site won't let me.  My first review follows this one.

I tried making this exactly as written, except I used 1 1/4 lbs of beef and upped the flour to 1/3 cup because I like a thick broth.  But I doubled the veggies and one can of beef broth (about 1 3/4 cups) didn't make enough liquid after it had cooked.  So I added another can of broth and doubled the salt and pepper too.  (Also added a small drained can of peas and mushrooms but that doesn't really change the taste.)  It is a very good recipe as written!  A basic and plain beef stew, but quite good.  I'm leaving my five star rating firmly in place.

(old review) I don't normally review by telling how I changed a recipe, but I did this one quite a bit.  I added two cans diced tomatoes and used frozen stew veggies instead of fresh.  It was very good and I'm sure it would be delish as-is, but I needed a bigger pot of stew than I was getting with the recipe so I did the tomatoes and frozen veggies to "stretch" it.

this was the first thing i made in my slow cooker and i was very happy at how it turned out! i cooked it on high for 5 hours and low on 1 hour and it turned out great. had to add some cornstarch at the end to thicken it up a bit. i also cut back on the paprika and added oregano, thyme, rosemary and parsley... it tastes even better the next day as leftovers because the flavours have mellowed and merged! great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this stew! I made a few changes based on other reviews though. I used 2-inch pieces of beef because one inch sounded way too small. I used 2c broth and 1/2c red wine, doubled the garlic and bay leaves and used 1T Worcestershire sauce. I also added mushrooms and a shallot (I think the mushrooms made a big difference!). I also browned the meat first, then rolled it in the flour which I had put into the bottom of the slow cooker. The meat left some good juice and brown bits in the pan so I sauteed the veggies in that for about 5 minutes before adding. I cooked it for about 5 hours and it was perfect - about medium thickness and with lots of broth which we loved.

This was a good base stew but as the other reviewers stated it made more of a broth than gravy.  Instead of using flour I coated my stew beef with a package of brown gravy mix followed the rest of the ingredients exactly, about 15 minutes before serving I thickened it with flour and water because we like stew with more gravy than broth.  Next time I will leave out the garlic the smell of it simmering all day just didn't smell like stew.  I served this with buttermilk biscuits, thanks for the recipe.

text:
This stew is great!  I tweaked it only a little adding a small can of V-8 juice and a packet of onion soup mix.  I eventually used only enough flour to coat the meat (otherwise it was way too thick) and left out the Worcestershire sauce cause it was too spicy in conjunction with the V-8 juice.  Also, I've done with and without the celery and found no difference so it's your personal preference!  Enjoy!!!

Great Stew!!  I did add a packet of brown gravy mix to the flour, and I used one can of beef broth.  The last hour, I checked it, the taste was a little bland so I added Mrs. Dash garlic seasoning and M.D. "tomato, basil, oregano" seasoning.  That made it so yummy!  The only problem I had was that the potatoes never did get completely done.  Maybe I'll put them in the crock first next time and put everything else on top.

What I like about this recipe is that it's very quick and simple to make. And the beauty of it is that you're not limited to the vegetables listed in the ingredients. However I held back on the spices a little bit. A couple hours before it was finished I found it to be bland so I simply added a bit more spices. It was ok at first but was a perfect leftover. Goes well with white rice and bread can be used to "clean" your dish!

text:
This was yummy and very easy, thank you! I've made this twice now. This time, I added some extra spices to suit our family's taste buds (extra garlic, extra Worcestershire sauce, turmeric, Chicago steak seasoning & chicken bouillon) and used chicken broth instead of beef broth and potatoes instead of celery because it's what I had on hand. Cooked on high in Crock-Pot for 6 hours. Served it over white rice and it was very hearty, yummy and the meat was very tender. This served dinner for 4 with enough leftovers for everyone for lunch the next day. Liked by all, even the 3 yr old and the picky husband :).

text:
Wow!  Mouth watering and delicious!  The meat is so tender and it's a family favorite.  Giving it 5 stars based on making the recipe exactly as written.  Over time, though, I've adjusted based on our family's taste: I've taken to using 1 can of beef broth because otherwise, there's a tiny bit left in the can that I always threw away.  Increased flour to 1/3 cup to accommodate the extra liquid.  I also use 2 bay leaves and 2 cloves of garlic.  Lately, I've also been adding 1 packet of slow cooker beef stew seasoning to give some extra flavor.  Delicious!  We're a family of four and it lasts us a couple of days.  I always serve with biscuits.  :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tastes almost as good as my favorite non-slower cooker recipe but with almost zero work.  I followed the recipe to a T and the results are very good.   

I have a favorite beef stew recipe that produces more complex flavors but calls for browning the beef, making a tomato paste/flour/wine mixture, simmering a beef/broth/onion mixture, adding vegetables and simmering a second time.   Say 1.5 hours compared with 5 minutes.

I would recommend using very lean beef.  Since there isn't a browning step all the fat ends up in the finished stew.
Review:
Rating:
2

text:
I like veggies and a rich flavor so I doubled the seasonings, produce and broth. I added 1 packet of McCormicks Beef Stew Seasoning, 1/2 packet of dry ranch seasoning, and splashed in 1/2 glass cabernet wine. This dinner turned out amazing! The meat melted in your mouth without all the extra browning/sautéing  steps. You can tell this type of recipe is perfect WITHOUT any changes as well and very easy to follow. Excited and impressed on my first pot roast thanks to this recipe!! The house smelled delicious and my roommates loved it. I made cheesy Texas toast and a side salad to put everyone in a food coma. Can't wait to make this again for the holidays and cold weather!

Display Name:
Julie Sailor
isPro:

82

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2115086.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Browned roast in pressure cooker, lid off.  Sauteed onion and garlic with spices (lavender, basil, oregano, salt, pepper, corriander, cumin, sage) and 1/3 cup flour.  Add onion to meat in pot.  Deglaze spices in pan with 1/3 cup red wine, 1 T worshtershire, 1/3 cup marinara, 1 cup water and 1 tsp beef bullion.  Added potatoes and carrots, pour on spice deglazing.

Pressure cook 15 min, slow cook 4 hrs.

Display Name:
Caitlyn Muniz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6765354.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just put it all together in my slow cooker and couldn't even see the broth. Slightly over 2 lbs of meat was used, 3 red potatoes, a small bag of baby carrots, 1 yellow onion and half a stalk of celery. The meat was coated just fine on the measurements given but I had to use 2 whole cartons of beef broth (Swanson less sodium) to get it to where I know a beef stew should be at. So then I added 2 more tsp of minced garlic (3 total), another 1/4 tsp of paprika, substituted the bay leaf for ground thyme (1/2 tsp total), and added a couple more dashes of Worcestershire sauce. I taught myself to cook by smell so I gave it a whiff and it smells how a beef stew should. Right on target. So if you use the measurements on this recipe I'd say cut the meat and veggies in half or double the liquids and herbs.

text:
I have made this stew so many times and I love it. Sometimes I do it just as the recipe says, other times I add other veggies that I have in my fridge that need to be used stat. Tonight I used sweet potato instead or normal, and I tossed in some mushrooms. Yummmmm. It's a favourite for cold winter nights like this.
(Also, I sometimes strain the liquid into a jug when everything is cooked, make a roux of flour and butter in a pot on the stove and then slowly whisk the stew liquid in so it makes a nice thick gravy/sauce which I then add back to the stew)

I made this as one other reviewer did by browning the meat, deglazing the pan with red wine, and some additional spices. One of the best crockpot meals I've made in a while. Use a wine you would drink for the deglazing. Look up wine types that are suggested for steak or beef stew. I used a 6 year old red blend.

text:
This stew is fantastic, I make it all the time.  I love the fact that you don't have to brown the beef first - it's a real time saver and I cannot taste any difference between the two methods.  The only things I change is that I add about a tsp of dried rosemary, and about 2 hours before the stew is finished I add  a cup of quartered button mushrooms.

text:
I made this on the stovetop and tweaked it just a little.  I browned the meat and onions together then doubled the broth (we like it with lots of liquid so we can make Bisquick dumplings on top at the end).  I added the spices/seasonings to the broth and let it simmer covered for a couple hours, added veggies and let it go another hour.  Then we finish with the dumplings.  It was a beautiful, rich and savory stew.

text:
I made a few changes as others had.  I dredged the meat (only one pound instead of 2 as I'd rather have more veg) in flour  (with salt and pepper), pan fried it in olive oil to seal in the juices and transferred it to the slow cooker.  Also, I was out while it was nearly cooked. Upon arriving back and checking the crock pot, I noticed there was not nearly enough broth as the meat was burning and everything was stuck to the bottom.  I added a lot more of the broth until it was the consistency I desired.  Delish!!!

text:
I made the recipe as stated.  It was easy to put together and I was pleased with the result.  I am not a picky eater though.  We used stew meat from Aldi, red potatoes that I chopped up, a yellow onion, beef broth from Aldi, and some carrots that I peeled and cut. No celery.  Cooked on high for 4 ours, then it sat on warm for another 2. The gravy was a nice consistency.  I also liked the texture of the meat, even though it wasn't browned beforehand. Next time I would salt the meat a little bit before tossing it in the flour.  This was great to throw together fast and end up with a great end result :)  Thank you!

It was the first time I made beef stew in a slow cooker and this recipe was delicious.  I did have to add another cup of beef broth and one half cup of water to make it more soupy because it literally boiled down to hardly no broth by hour 3.

text:
I've made this a few times now with the following mods:
- browned meat in cast iron in beef tallow
- cooked onions in tallow and beef juices until soft
- deglaze pan with red wine and added deglaze sauce
- used 1tbsp Worcestershire instead of 1tsp
- 2 Bay leaves
- 2 cup bone broth instead of 1.5c beef broth

30 min on high in InstaPot

IMO, it's the best stew I've ever made.

text:
Both teens and parents enjoyed this stew, and it was easy to make!  Changes for next time: I will probably add another potato, and 2 more carrots or so, as I didn't feel like there was a good enough balance of vegetables, compared to meat.  The recipe could use some more!  Also, instead of only using 1-1/2 cups of broth, I would go ahead and use 2 cups.....  The meat cubes that were on the top got browned and dried, because there was not enough broth to cover it all.  Other than that, it worked for me.....  a good, hearty meal that warms the house, on a chilly winter day!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I started out by following the recipe almost exactly - but ended up having to make some adjustments. I’m giving the original recipe 4-stars. I found this to need significantly more liquid - I added an extra 1-cup of beef broth towards the end of the cooking time. I also found the flavor to be seriously lacking and so I used a lot more Worcestershire sauce (2 Tbsp vs the originally called for 1 tsp) and also added about 1/4 cup of tomato paste and 1 tsp of dried herbes de Provence. Additionally, I bulked up the veggies to 4 potatoes, 4 carrots and 3 stalks of celery and added the veggies about halfway through the cooking time so they didn’t turn to mush. We were very happy with the way this turned out after the adjustments made (my 18-month old daughter even ate it!) but as is it was pretty bland.

text:
Delicious!!!! It is a keeper!!! Simple!!! Tasty!!! I have to admit that I added a couple of extra ingredients because I want the Sabor Boricua in my stew. So this is what I did! I Seasoned the meat with Adobo and Sazón with culantro and achiote for color. Browned the meat,  add Sofrito with the rest of the ingredients and a large can of stew tomatoes. I left the broth for last to be able to control the amount of liquid in my stew. I didn’t want it to be too runny!

userID:

Display Name:
marcibeau
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night fo company, and we all liked it...a lot. I made it  just like the recipe without the celery: just my preference, but I don't like celery in stew, just in soups. No need to brown meat first. Based on one other review, I added 1/2 extra cup (2 total ) of the beef broth, cooked it on low for 5 1/2 hours,adding a slurry of cornstarch and water to thicken the gravy. I felt like that was a mistake, it was too thick for my taste. I also added 4 oz. of sliced mushrooms towards the end. They really don't change the taste, just add another texture. I feel like this is a great stew, especially if you have children. You can add or omit any veg you like,according to your family's taste . Beefy, comforting, delicious.  It made 4 generous servings. This is very similar to the beef stew I grew up on.

TODAY....I made again, omitting celery, added 1/2 cup red wine, increased Worchestershire to 1 TBSP, 2 bay leaves. Added mushrooms the last 1 1/2 hours, and frozen peas, the last 1/2 hour. I did not make a slurry,and the sauce is perfect, as is the taste. It is a little more rustic, a little more seasoned and rich with the addition of the wine and Worchetershire. I gave a five based on the original recipe, as it is delicious, and a perfect family meal. All good cooks know that you cook, taste, and adjust to your  taste. If I had TOTALLY turned it around, like many reviewers, I would submit my own recipe. It does a disservice to the original recipe, and is not helpful to t
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

city:
