region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a terrific basic stew but like all crockpot dishes, it needs "finishing" at the end. I made it exactly as written, with the small exception of using 2 cloves of garlic rather than one. To finish it, I added a splash of dry red wine 30 minutes before serving and then sprinkled a small handful of shredded Colby-Jack cheese on top to serve. It was very good, very hearty. It could be finished with plenty of other things too, maybe sour cream, chives, fresh chopped onions, etc.

Meh. I found this to be okay, but the flavour was seriously boring and I followed this recipe to a T (I did double it though).

Display Name:
Chelsea Porter
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3033063.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First try: followed the basic recipe, just added some quantity -- 2.5 lbs bottom round, 1 lb sliced baby bella mushrooms, an extra potato, about 2 cloves' worth of minced garlic, and a total 1 lb of baby carrots. Upped the beef stock to 2.5 cups to account for the extra quantity, and left out the bay leaf because I don't keep them on hand. 

- About 5 hours into cooking (on high), I added a roux of 1/4c butter and 1/2c flour, because the liquid was more souplike than stewlike, and that thickened it up beautifully. Served it up after 6 hours on high, and the texture was wonderful, both of the ingredients and the stew liquid. It ended up a bit bland for my taste, but I look forward to trying to remedy that on future tries by altering spices.

--- Second try: 2lbs meat, 1 large baking potato, 1lb carrots, 1/2lb mushrooms, 3 ribs celery, 2 cups broth, 2 cloves garlic, extra salt + pepper + Worcestershire, fresher paprika. cooked on high for first hour, then low for about 6. near end of cooking time, added small amounts (less than 1/4 tsp each) of thyme, cinnamon, and soy sauce to punch up the flavor, plus a beurre manie of 3tbsp flour + 2tbsp butter to thicken the sauce. really deepened the flavor, and turned out purely lovely
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful basic beef stew recipe. I’ve made it several times but with a few of my own personal tweaks (more beef, less potatoes, no celery, etc.). I don’t feel it’s necessary to sauté anything, why make work? Just season the beef with the flour and seasonings in a big plastic bag and then plunk it in the crockpot, adding your own personal touches. It’s so easy. I also add a pack of McCormick's beef stew seasoning. 

During the last 45 minutes or so of cooking I add a 16oz. bag of frozen peas, which makes it colorful and even more nutritious. Fabulous!

country:
None
text:
FOR RICHER FLAVOR ADD: 1 can diced tomatoes and 3 oz (1/2 small can) tomato paste.
Reduce beef broth to 1 1/4 c.
Add seasoning salt to taste (I prefer liberal amounts of Johnny's).
Step 1: Mix flour, 1 tsp. salt, and 1/2 tsp. pepper into a gallon Ziploc bag then add stew meat and shake well.
Step 2: Combine meat with all other ingredients in crock pot on High for 4 hrs.
Good simple crockpot stew!

Great recipee to teach how to make beef stew though.

I'll start off by saying I made this exactly as the recipe stated.  It was extremely easy and I was skeptical because you did not brown the beef first.  However, it turned out very well.  I did not give it 5 stars as I did have to add some more spices (I added kitchen bouquet after the stew was all cooked and we tasted it).  What i really liked about this recipe was the fact that it was quick and while not exactly with the same depth of flavor a "traditional" stew has, very good. I will definitely make it again, especially if I need a good flavorful hearty meal in a hurry

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy and tastes great. I follow the directions and don't brown the meat. Changes I make: A bit more garlic and celery, a large sweet onion, one more bay leaf, 14.5 oz can of reduced-sodium beef broth.

I save the carrots to go in after 2/3 cooking time (using 12 oz of mini baby carrots), and add them with 12 oz snapped fresh green beans and 8 oz fresh sliced mushrooms.

The extra fluid makes for a slightly thinner sauce, but since I use lean meat, add more vegetables, and freeze in portions as whole meals, that helps moisturize the meat.

text:
Great recipe! I made it several times "as is" without any modifications other than occasionally using chicken broth instead of beef, and excluding celery (not a fan). I tried browning the meat one time. But quite frankly I wouldn't say it tasted much different, especially after 8 hours of slow cooking. All it really does is just giving your meat a nice color, but other than and I think it's just an unnecessary extra step that takes more time.

Although Corinne's version sounds good too. Maybe I'll try that next time.

userID:
8662480
Display Name:
judy2304

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/871418.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to give this recipe 5 stars as it is a good basic beef stew as written. I doubled the recipe, added extra on the veggies, and added 1/2 cup red wine. For the beef broth, I used homemade beef broth that I always keep on hand. Broth from the store has less food value and less taste. After I put in the 3 cups of broth for a double recipe, it didn't look like enough, so I added another 3 cups to almost cover everything. At this point, it didn't fit in my 6-quart slow cooker, so I poured it all into a stock pot, and cooked it on my NuWave cook top at 195 degrees for 12 hours. I did have to add a corn starch/water mixture (3 T. corn starch and 3 T. water) to thicken the gravy. Next time, I will cut back on the broth quantity so there isn't so much gravy, although more gravy would be better over mashed potatoes or noodles. One suggestion I would have for other trying this stew is to cut the meat into 2" x 2" squares since it shrinks to half during the cook time.
Review:
Rating:
1

text:
This stew was really good. I tweaked it a little as follows since I am on a low sodium diet.  I added two more carrots, one more potato, McCormick Herb Gravy Mix, two small cans no salt tomato sauce and omitted the salt, garlic and bay leaf. The gravy was really good. I cooked for 4-1/2 hours on high - carrots and meat could have cooked longer. Would do 6 hours next time

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this stew based on the 4.5/5 star ratings from over 4K reviewers. Unfortunately, I fail to understand how it is rated so highly. It was the first and last time I’ll use this recipe. Like many others, I had to make modifications such as doubling the beef broth (the amount in the recipe wasn’t nearly enough to accommodate the other ingredients) and doubling the amount of carrots and celery (the amount called for just did not look like much at all, unless you don’t like veggies). In the end, it turned out extremely bland. I do like the fact that the recipe was simple to follow as well as it taking nearly no time at all to prep. My 9yr old picky eater wouldn’t touch it (no surprise); my husband and I had one bowl and saved the remaining stew hoping it might have more flavor the next day- it didn’t. I was really looking forward to this recipe, but it’s just not something that tastes very good. If this was a dish at your favorite restaurant, you wouldn’t be ordering this more than once.

Came out great, I wanted a stew for the crock pot without a lot of prep. This worked I cut up all of the vegetables the night before and left them in a big measuring cup in the broth, except the potatoes. Put everything in the crock before going to work and added the potatoes when I got home and let them cook on high until done. I did use parsnip instead of carrot because we had a fresh bag. It was great and we will do this again! Thanks Steve

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's an OK recipe, but needs tweaks.
1) I sub'd Celery for Asparagus.
2) I used Smoked Paprika, and more of it.
3) I used more Spuds and Veggies w/ the specified amount of beef or more. You will have a 'beefier' stew and more of it.
4) The beef should be lightly browned in a pan before going into the pot, because you may have too much saturated fat in your stew otherwise, even if you trimmed your beef. Unless sat fat is your thing, then drop it in. There won't be that much of a difference in texture and/or taste.

text:
I enjoyed this recipe above most others.  It's much simpler to put everything in the slow cooker and for the most part leave it untouched.   I'd recommend if you want to pan fry your meat in oil.. use  a different recipe since this recipe is based on a one dish meal. I added a little more potato and carrots,  and used 1/3 cup flour instead of 1/4. The only notable difference I made though to the recipe, is I put the flour in the stew as a thickening agent instead of coating the meat with it. I like a flavorful sauce... otherwise I wouldn't be using  a slow cooker. My wife and family all love din and I plan to keep this recipe in my kitchen.

text:
I adjusted the recipe to be gluten-free, using GF Bisquick with  1 Tbsp arrowroot.  Used 1/2 C of that mixture to toss the meat using gallon plastic bag.  No need to saute' the meat separately.  Turned out tender and succulent.  I replaced Worcestershire sauce with A-1 steak sauce due to availability and added a Tbsp of Merlot.  The flavor pop was fabulous.  Made a large batch to make freezer meals!  Even better rewarmed!

text:
Fantastic Find!!  Superb flavor, this is by far the best recipe for Beef Stew and I've been making it for years.  Following some of the comments I also made some changes...  I added a packet of  Beef Stew Seasoning Mix and a 14.5 oz can of beef broth and since I didn't have paprika I substituted with Sriacha Seasoning (which gave it a little too much bite) I also put in a dash of celery seed and a some fresh parsley.  I then added all the other ingredients, although I did add more of the carrots and potatoes.  I cooked the stew on high for 5 hours, stirring every 40 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe Buchko's way and acc to Corinne's review. I was thrilled that it worked out just fine w/o pre-browning beef. (Browning the beef cubes on as many sides as possible as Beef Institute recommends renders a very dark, rich gravy so if you have the time it can't hurt, of course.) I have a 6 quart crockpot so to fill the crock with stew I used the 2 lbs of beef, 1 onion, and 1/2 tsp pepper but I tripled the flour to 3/4 cup and poured in the full 32 oz vacuum-packed box of beef broth at the end. Made plenty of gravy!  I had added plenty of those small roasting potatoes, whole; an extra carrot or two and additional celery. The liquid then covered the ingredients almost completely which I understand is important when braising meat. The seasonings I played with, too. I didn't want to triple all the herbs necessarily but trying to make a flavorful stew is a challenge. I added a small kick of heat with 1/2 teaspoon of Spicely Organic Rib Eye Seasoning. That's the small economical boxes of organic herbs you can find most anywhere now.  I'll definitely be making again and again.

text:
I combined the original with some of Corinne's ideas. I increased the flour to 1/3 cup, worchestershire sauce to 1 Tb and added 1/2 cup red wine that I had reduced down to about 1/4 cup. I did not saute the meat first or anything though. As the recipe is written I put the meat in the bottom raw and stirred the flour/seasonings in. I had to use the high setting, and it was done in 6 hours, truly it would have been done in 4.5 hours. Will make again!

text:
I made this recipe as is and honestly I don't know why it receives such good ratings. It was very bland with no depth of flavor and was quite thin. I tasted it about 3 hours into cooking on high and decided to add more Worcestershire sauce, salt, and pepper and it was still bland. I also added some frozen sweet corn and cornstarch to thicken. I won't make this exact recipe again. It could definitely benefit from some more herbs and spices like thyme, rosemary, onion powder, and more garlic. I would also probably add a bullion cube in addition to beef broth to help deepen the beef flavor.

This is the best and easiest no brainer for beef stew I’ve ever done. Everyone raved about this dish.  We added more potatoes and carrots than what was called for because we all like our veggies.  Be sure to watch your cooker because our stew was ready much sooner than indicated by the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you want bland boiled beef from a Siberian work camp, then this is the recipe for you! Seriously, don’t use standard beef broth, and certainly not 2.5 cups. Make a reduced beef broth or stock before (I know, adds time - but you can let it simmer on the stove while you do other things). Use your own stock as a base (1.5 - 2 cups Max) and get rewarded with a rich, rub hugging, dense beef stew that you were longing for when this journey began.

None
country:
None
text:
I have made a similar version of this beef stew for years. It is an excellent recipe. Like others, I prefer to brown my meat first (learned that from my mother). I also will then saute the veggies as well. I usually use onions, celery, carrots and mushrooms. Sometimes I will throw in a parsnip and or a turnip as well. I also deglaze the pan after sauteing . I use small red potatoes instead of dicing larger ones, that is just my preference and I don't think it matters either way.  If I have some herbs in my garden I will add them to the stew as well e.g. fresh rosemary and/or thyme. The house smells great and it is an easy meal to put together.  An easy way to thicken the stew is to add instant potatoes rather than cornstarch. It gives it a nice flavor and texture.

Question:  How will this do if I freeze the leftovers and reheat next week? This is in the crock pot now.  Although I halved the recipe., there is still too much for the two of us.  It  filled up my  2 1/2  qt. pot.  So I am cooking it on high for 6 hours to be sure the potato's are done. ( I assume a full pot takes longer to cook?)
I made this last year in a 4 qt. slow cooker  (1/2 recipe) and thought it lacked flavor.  So this time I put in a yellow onion instead of a sweet onion, and increased the Worcester sauce.  Celery seed instead of celery also. And I am using the smaller pot for the half recipe.

I followed the recipe exactly, with one exception: since I have a Ninja System, I used the "stovetop" setting to brown the meat first, then switched it over to the "slow cook" setting and set it on low for 10 hours. The stew was absolutely amazing, meat super tender, and full of flavor!  This is how I will cook beef stew all the time from now on!

text:
This is a great stew that satisfied a craving I'd had for a while. I followed the recipe exactly but doubled everything except the meat (only had 3 pounds) and it turned out perfectly. If youre going to double it, put in on high for the first half (5 hours) and then low for the rest of the time (5 hours). The only thing I would change next time, out of preference, is add cabbage (used to having it when I was younger) and maybe add some more broth part way through (by the time the liquid thicknened there wasnt really anything for the bread to soak up).

text:
I made this exactly as the recipe stated.  It was really easy and came out perfect.   All of my instincts told me to brown the meat, but I decided to follow the recipe to the letter, and brown next time if I needed to. 
Wow! There really is no need.  The stew was thick and rich.  I wouldn't change anything.

***Update.   I made this again but discovered that I was out of celery half way through.   Omitting the celery produced a very bland mediocre stew.  I went out and bought  celery the following day, added it to the stew and cooked it in the slow cooker for another couple of hours.  The stew was saved!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2026337.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!!!  I put the beef stew meat (mine was in larger chunks) in a bag with flour, salt and pepper and then browned it in olive oil in batches.  Once that was transferred to the cooker, I added onion + garlic (I used 2 cloves) to the same pan, and once that became fragrant I added the celery and carrots.  When that softened, I put the beef broth and the 1 t worcestershire in the pan to deglaze it before dumping in the cooker.  I also added 1/2 cup red wine, and used 2 fresh bay leaves and really good paprika.  Amazing flavor.  What I loved is that the liquid hardly needed any stovetop reduction at the end, just a little seasoning, and there was only a tiny bit of fat (I used a fat separator anyway out of habit!)  The house smelled SOOOO good all day!

text:
Super easy but it's currently cooking so I'll let you know how it tastes later (wish this site allowed us to write down notes first)...
I combined this recipe and another recipe because this recipe is for a crockpot while the other isn't... so we'll see how it turns out.
I used Beef round tip roast and cut it into cubes (cheaper by almost half instead of buying the "beef stew cubes" and looks the same.)
I used 2 cans of beef broth (didn't measure out 1.5cups)
1tsp. parsley
1tsp. rosemary
and the rest was the recipe.

If I had time, i'd sauté them before putting them into the crockpot... seals in the favor.

text:
Great exactly as is. Next time I will try Corinne's suggestions to see the difference.
Corinne's suggestions:
1. Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.

text:
I always had a difficult time making beef stew because I just couldn't get the liquid thick enough.  I would keep adding flour and then you know what happens when you do that.  :)

This recipe took care of my problem and was easy to make and quite flavorful and tasty.

We had some crusty Italian bread with it.  I actually put my bread on the bottom of the bowl and poured the stew over the bread.  YUM!!

The recipe is perfect the way it is.

Thanks.

Display Name:
Matthew Woodward
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3841762.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first placed the beef into a ziploc bag containing 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon pepper and 1 teaspoon of Montreal Steak Spice, tossed it to coat; then seared the beef in a pan. While it was cooking I added 8 ounces of chopped Shitake mushrooms and let them soak up the beef flavour before placing it all into my crockpot. Added 1 1/2 cups beef broth, 1/4 cup Marsala wine, 3 cloves garlic, 2 whole bay leaves (remove at end), 2 tablespoons paprika, 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce, chopped/diced 3 onions, 3 potatoes, 7 sweet carrots, 2 stalks celery. 5 hours on high, 2 hours on low. Beef was melt in your mouth delicious.

It was very good.  I had modified it based on some other comments - 1/3 cup flour instead of 1/4, lightly searing meat before adding to pan, 2 garlic instead of 1, 1 tbsp of Worcestershire instead of 1 tsp - so the review isn't true of the exact recipe.  Besides the changes I already made, the only thing I'd like to change for next time is that there wasn't quite enough liquid at the bottom - I may try adding a little more broth next time.  But overall, very tasty!

text:
Delicious!  Exactly what I am looking for in a stew.
Historically, I would shake the beef in the flour mixture, and sear it in frying pan, prior to putting in the crockpot.  As I read through reviews, I saw people saying to do this, but I also said reviews saying not to, as its not needed.  I followed the recipe exactly, and it came out great.  
I assume its the pepper, but it was pretty spicy.  My husband and I loved that, but I would def adjust that if I plan to serve to kids again.  Too much for them.  My dad likes pepper too, but he suggested putting less in future, and let people add as they desire.

country:
None
text:
I added herbs de Provence and Bragg's liquid aminos (similar to soy sauce), but it was still bland. Also, the potatoes did not get soft enough, even with the maximum cooking time. I refrigerated most of this dish overnight. It tasted much better the second day because the potatoes had softened in the gravy. If I cooked it again, I'd microwave the potatoes first; I find that vegetables often fail to cook thoroughly in slow-cooker stew recipes even if layered under the faster-cooking meat.

I loved how easy this recipe was.  The beef, which I didn't brown first, turned out so tender!  I personally like the potatoes really soft, which wasn't the case, but I didn't have more time to cook it - everyone was hungry.  I'll cut them smaller next time. We eat this some Italian bread.  Great recipe for the slow cooker!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Increased flour to 1/3 C; decreased pepper to 1/4 teaspoon, used season salt instead of regular salt, added 1 package of McCormick Beef Stew seasoning.  I mixed the flour, seasoned salt, paprika, and pepper together, dredged the chunks of meat in flour mixture, heated up 1 Tablespoon of oil in a pan and browned the meat with the chunks of onions.  Mixed a can of beef broth with McCormick mix along with other seasoning ingredients.  Added meat to crockpot, poured in liquid mixture and added veggies in order of the recipe.  SO GOOD!

text:
Very good and easy to assemble as written.  Any stew can have veggie variations per taste and what is on hand.
And all slow cooker recipe users can choose to brown the meat first or not based on experimentation.
While I do agree with Canucky and Lindsey B about rating the recipe as given or post your own version as a separate recipe - think of all the individual recipes you would have to look at instead of just reading a few reviews for some ideas that might appeal for modifications.  I personally like reading a few reviews that describe alterations and really don't pay attention to the rating as much.

text:
This is how I first made my beef stew. I have changed it here and there to suit my taste or for what I have available. I've read many reviews that have changed it so much that it's not the same recipe. That may be annoying to some, maybe even the author of the original recipe. But I for one love to try different ways of making recipes. So I like reading the reviews with the changes in case I see something to add that makes it taste better or go farther or cost less. No one is changing it on the original page. Just for their own particular liking. I always welcome remarks that will make my meals good.
By the way I've always loved this recipe it is quick, easy and very tasty.

i was missing some ingredients so I had to make some adjustments but it still turned out delicious! text:
Great stew!  I used 1.75 pounds of sirloin steak, red new potatoes, multi colored carrots , celery and 3 onions.  I coated the cubed steak in Gluten free flour with salt and pepper, browned in vegetable oil and I added 4 cups of beef broth 
(from bouillon) to the crock pot.  I also sauteed the onion in the skillet before adding to the crock pot.  My family loved it!

smcdade

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so delicious! I made it exactly as written, including not browning the beef. I really don't think you need to brown the beef as it is going to be cooking for a long time which will be getting it tender anyway. Also you're saving yourselves some calories from oil if you don't pre-brown the meat. One thing that I will say is that I did end up adding a little extra flour and water for thickening. At the time that I was going to serve it, I opened the lid and it looked a little too liquidy to me, so I mixed about a tbsp of flour with some water and threw it in there and came back in 10 mins. It did the trick. I cooked mine on high for about 4.5 hours and it was perfect. I wouldn't recommend cooking it any longer as the meat will get too tender and start breaking apart. Also, I used bottom round roast and it worked great.

text:
Great for my very first slow cooker recipe!  I really appreciated the simplicity of it.  The original is great and so are the different versions!  I loved that there were so many people with their personal twists and comments.  I started with Corinne's suggestions which gave me the courage to try and be creative on my own.  I like using pomegranate juice instead of wine...I'm also lazy so I love the Trader Joe's pre-cut onions, garlic cloves and paste (I always toss in extra cloves into the mix), baby carrots, mini potatoes (wash and toss in cooker), pre-cut stew meat.  (Homer Simpson: "so lazy....") Also, I think the Trader Joe's beer bread goes great with this. I don't work for Trader Joe's but they were sampling these and they are so easy to make--just add beer (or soda water) and butter on top and bake.  Super fast if you make them in small muffin tins (10-15 minutes!)  YUMMY!!!! ok i think i am going to have to have this for dinner tonight.

text:
This was kind of bland, and there was too much meat. It did cook beautifully in my slow cooker though, so I'll make it again but cut the meat to 1.5 lbs and add more seasonings.

Update:
I've made this three times now and have changed my rating from 3 to 4 stars with the following minor changes: Reduce beef to 1.5 lbs, and double the garlic, bay leaf, paprika, and Worcestershire. Optionally, add a teaspoon or two of your favorite herbs and/or spices. The flavor is SO much better, as is the ratio of meat to veggies.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I set up my account just to leave this review. I made this stew, but I want to warn you that it is extremely bland if you do not season it properly!

First, make sure that you DO NOT use low sodium beef broth, I found it bland even with the regular full sodium beef broth

Second, increase the spices. You need more flavour in this dish, trust me! I strongly recommend increasing the Worcestershire sauce, at least double it. Add a couple extra bay leaves. Triple the black pepper and salt. I don't really notice the paprika but it seemed to be enough. Honestly I suck at spices so look them up or combine from different recipes, all I know is that the flavour is lacking.

Third, salt salt salt. I believe the most lacking thing in this dish was the salt content. I did add more ingredients than recommended (extra celery, extra meat) but not much more. If you prefer low-sodium then don't add more, but if not the dish would go from OK to AMAZING with just some extra salt and spices.

userID:
3429009
Display Name:
SSwisher
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:

220
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We like a stew with more gravy, so I used about 3 cups of low sodium beef broth, so I doubled up on the spices with the exception of paprika (I ran out).  I also left out the garlic for personal preference.  Like most, I doubled up on the carrots and potatoes, but wish I hadn't as we like a meatier stew.  I cooked for 1 hr on high, then 8 on low and my meat was more shredded consistency than stew cubes (my fault for cutting to small of cubes).   I should have added more flour to the meat (since I increased the beef stock), so at the end I removed a good portion of the liquid from the slow cooker and thickened in up with corn starch on the stovetop.    This way we had a ton of thick gravy.  Next time I will cut back on the potatoes and carrots, but add peas and mushrooms (and maybe green beans too).  Spice wise though, this is a very nice, traditional stew that is a great base recipe and easy to customize to your family's preferences.  We will definitely have at a family meal this fall.
Review:

5

If you want credit for a recipe, list one! But don't tell me the changes you made to someone else's recipe. Because, then it is a different recipe. Rate the recipe as written, to show respect for the person who submitted it. I actually like that BUCHKO made it as easy as possible as a crock pot recipe should be. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3569055.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy and very basic stew recipe. I skipped the celery (since my husband hates it), and just upped the onion by about half. I brown the beef in a skillet, poured that on top of the potatoes and carrots, reduced a little red wine in the skillet (to get all the nummy beef bits and flavor), and poured that into the crock pot with the beef broth. 

If you like a thicker stew, I recommend scooping some of the hot broth into a measuring cup, adding a little bit or cornstarch or flour, whisking until blended, and pouring back into the slow cooker.

I also do a "stroganoff" variation by thickening the broth, and stirring in some sour cream just before serving!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Loved it and it was so easy!  None of that searing the meat beforehand, etc, etc.  I will make this again for sure.  The great thing about stew is that it's so versatile.  I followed the recipe as closely as I could but had to make the following changes: I used gluten-free flour instead of wheat flour.  I reduced the amount of sodium by using low sodium beef broth and 1/4 tsp of sea salt instead of 1/2 tsp regular salt.  I didn't have carrots or celery, so I used parsnips (?) and fennel (??) instead (I don't know why I had the more obscure ingredients).  Since I wasn't using an orange coloured veggie (as in the carrots), I swapped out one of the potatoes for a sweet potato.  It was excellent.  So, feel free to mix and match the veggies to change things up or suit whatever you have on hand!

text:
I used low sodium beef broth, added 3 crushed cloves garlic, didn’t add celery or salt. I will probably use half the recommended paprika next time, it wasn’t too spicy but it didn’t make it feel like beef stew.  I did add a little more potatoes and carrots since I didn’t add celery.  I tried to remove as much fat from the beef and cooked on high for 4.5 hours, this was enough time for potatoes and beef to be tender.  I’ll definitely keep making this recipe over and over.

Display Name:
E Christina Dabis-Appleby

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3359620.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh ~~SO~~ good.  I made it "AS-IS" and the stew is the best I have ever made and the best I have ever eaten!  

I doubled the recipe.  I mixed the dry ingredients together and then dropped the beef chunks into that seasoned mix.  Then, I browned the meat.  While it was browning, I dissolved 2 cubes of Beef Bullion (Knoll's) in  2 cups of hot water.  

Then, I added the dry ingredients to the beef bullion liquid and blended them thoroughly (I used a large quart container, and shook the daylights out of it).  

I used bay leaves from our own tree.  

WOW!!  I cannot wait to make this again, and again, and again!

text:
I only gave it 4 stars because the written directions are slightly different than the video. The video instructs you to add the paprika with the flour mixture, and the written directions do not. And, the written directions tell you to slow cook for 10-12 hours (which is what I followed), but the video tells you 8. So needless to say, it was overly tender and the potatoes were a little on the over-done side. 

That said, I would definitely make it again (following the video instructions of course).  Very flavorful and easy to make!!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6533266.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We used my Wildtree on this recipe and changed a few things. First patted meat dry and browned sides in Wildtree Tuscan Oil then tossed in 1/4 cup flour with 1tsp Wildtree Java Rub and and a bit of salt before adding to crock pot. Then minced an onion and sweat it out in left over oil to add to the pot. Added diced carotts and red potatoes then mixed in 1 tsp Wildtree worcestershire into 1 1/2 cups of water along with 1 cup tomato sauce to pour over beef. Dropped in a bay leaf and cooked 6hrs on low. KIDS LOVED IT! THANKS for a GREAT base recipe!
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this stew and it was just okay.  The stew cooked just fine in the crockpot for the allotted time.  I followed this recipe and dumped the meat in the pot and dumped the flour and seasonings and stirred it around.  Added all the seasonings in the required amount except for the amount of broth.  That was a lot of liquid for a crock pot.  The stew cooked for a full 12 hrs and was very tender.  Veggies were perfect.  However, the stew was way too bland.  There needed to be something added.  The hubby was seasoning with salt and pepper but even then....still was bland in flavor.  It was also too watery... I let it sit but it did not thicken up so I had to scoop some liquid and veggies and I put them in a blender and pureed it and added it back to the stew.  It thickened up right away after that.  I would make this again but I would put in A LOT more of seasoning.s.

text:
I took Corinnes suggestions, it was terrific. Instead of buying the beef stew cubes ,I purchased the meat like a london broil. I cut the meat in strips and tenderized it with a metal mallet . Then I cubed it in bite size pieces. I have always found stew meat tough ,but by tenderizing it & then cutting it myself made it VERY tender. I will never buy pre-cut stew meat again.

text:
This is a good base recipe to make your own.  I have made this twice and both times I made a flour dredge using Montreal steak seasoning, paprika and season-all.  I also added a cup of cabernet.  This all went into the oven in my dutch oven at 325° for 2.5 hrs.   The second time I used some leftover bacon grease in addition to veggie oil to brown the meat.  Added a whole extra dimension of flavor.  Either way it was excellent.

text:
Yes it is bland.  It needs probably double the seasonings.  And if you want more sauce/broth, use at least 2C beef broth.  Add more at the end if you want more soupy consistancy.  Once I added a TON of seasoning, it was good.  My variations are: 2 celery, 3 large carrots, 2 red potatoes.  In my seasonings, I included: Seasoning Salt, Garlic Salt & Onion Salt.

None
text:
Compare with five-hour-stew oven recipes.  I make seasoned flour (flour, salt, pepper) and coat the beef chunks in it, then lightly brown them before putting in slow cooker.  I know it's an extra step, but I feel better about it, and it thickens without the floury lumps seen in  the  recipe photo.  I also add a couple of whole cloves; just be careful not to serve them.

text:
I made the recipe as directed and found myself with a good base for customizing the stew for our preferences later down the road. I will probably be more aggressive with the seasoning next time and use only two potatoes (as the potatoes we have in the Pacific Northwest are usually pretty huge), as well as add a bit more broth to the recipe because the liquid did not cover the entire mass, leaving the stew with some patchy/dry pieces of meat and potato. Not perfect, but exactly what I was looking for - a recipe I can adapt for my slow cooking needs!

This recipe tasted just like my dad's. I took the basic recipe and tweaked it some though. I browned off the meat on the stove and softened the potatoes a little on the stove as well. I also threw in carrots and broccoli. For me I also doubled the seasonings as well. I prefer seasoning salt over regular salt as well more flavor in my opinion. I also just used water simply because the beef will make it's own broth and I used a beef cube just for extra beefy flavor.

text:
Use good filet, 6 instead of 4 carrots, and add green beans. Also add few spoonfuls of canned corn (drained).  Add  Italian parsley and herbs to flour mixture.  

Add additional flour to thicken broth as needed.  After tasting, as needed add salt, worcheshire sauce, lowry's, pepper.  Serve with sourdough rolls.  Heated on high for 4 - 4-1/2 hours.

text:
I made this exactly according to the recipe and it was passable, but not particularly good and the beef was chewy. To be fair, I think I've concluded there is no way to make good beef (or chicken) in a slow cooker,  much as I REALLY want there to be. That said, this recipe is somewhat bland and watery, so if you're expecting a rich, hearty stew you won't find it with this recipe. Some of the tweaks might get you there but I think the only way to do is to do it properly in a dutch oven or something similar.

I add chopped turnip.  Instead  of using regular potatoes, i put in the mini potatoes, not cut in half. I add 1 cup of frozen peas 20 minutes before the end cook time. I also brown my meat using the flour recommended and add the remaining flour as directed. At the end, I drain the stew and thicken the gravy, adjust the seasonning and return evreything to the crockpot to keep warm until serving. Hearty and delicious!

None
text:
Flavour was good, beef was very tender.
Timing was such that I cooked it 5 and half hours on high. (Recipe says 4-6.) The recipe doesn't have enough water to support this cooking time, and some of the beef and veggies at the outside of the pot ended up slightly burnt. If you choose to use one of the longer cooking times add additional liquids, either more broth or simply water.

city:

country:

text:
Delicious and so easy. I added an extra can of broth because I like my stew more on the soupy side. This is maybe not as umami as some of the fancier beef recipes out there, but it is hearty, comforting, and really just yummy without requiring much in the way of cost or effort. You just chop a few of things, toss some stuff into a crock pot, and you're done. You get a pretty big payoff for such a small effort. Perfect recipe for busy weekdays in cold weather. I will make this again and again. (However ... if you're looking to cook something for a special occasion, I'd recommend Cooking Light's Provencal Beef Daube instead -- it will cost more to make, dirty more dishes, and take more time to prep, but the result is absolutely wonderful).

I have made this recipe several times and everyone loves it. My daughter, who is very picky, has been begging for it for the past couple of weeks so I am making it today with a fresh supply of potatoes, carrots, and garlic from the garden and fresh stew beef from the half a side we just picked up last week (I love fall)! I follow the directions to the 'T' with one exception: I add an extra half cup or so of beef broth only because my crock loses liquids on long cooks and I noticed my potatoes dried and burned on my first attempt. After the change, it has turned out excellent each time! Bon Appétit!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was a great, easy recipe! I made this pretty much as-is (like another reviewer, I think that when you make a zillion tweaks, you might as well post your own version as your own recipe). I threw everything in the crock pot according to the recipe -- with 4 kids, I don't have time for all that pre-browning nonsense. I think I threw in a little extra flour just to make the sauce thicker. I think this would be so easy to add more or different vegetables (some sliced mushrooms would be delicious, or add some sweet potato for something unusual and healthy). One thing I will do differently next time, just for my own taste, is to make more sauce by adding more broth. In any case, this is a winner recipe for my family!

text:
I loved this recipe as a base. I added fresh corn off the cob, extra potatoes and increased the onion and Worcestershire sauce by 1/2 teaspoon. I added 2 Bay leaves instead of 1. I also added 1/2 teaspoon of Johnny's seasoning salt, a packet of McCormick au jus, and at the end, 1/4 cup of heavy whipping cream. It was AMAZING! Best I've ever made. We like to top our stew with sauerkraut and horseradish. My children don't like those things so they opted for ketchup. Surprisingly the ketchup added a sweet tangy flavor. All around amazing and can't wait to make it again. Next time I will brown the stew meat in canola oil (couple tablespoons) before adding to the slow cooker.

text:
One of the easiest slow cooker beef stew recipes I've found and the final product was GREAT! The only two changes I made to the recipe was that 1) I used 3/4 cup beef broth and 3/4 cup red cooking wine and 2) I added mushrooms. I served mine over mashed cauliflower with garlic and butter (a low-carb alternative to mashed potatoes) & it was a big hit!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy enough to get started but the recipe lacked complexity.  
Easy upgrades without adding stuff to wash in the sink:

Add up to 2-4 table spoons of ketchup or even better, tomato paste.  Taste for balance.
Add 2 tb of sugar.
To add oomph to the beef, marinate it for 15-20 min in 2 tb of soy sauce and coat with the flour (as the recipe directs).  
If you wanna be fancy, add some orange peel and remove after slow cooking.  I also would swap out some of the broth with a can of beer instead.  =)

These steps to me, add a bit of sweetness and acidity to play off the mushy saltiness of the broth.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks BUCHKO - Surprisingly good considering minimal seasonings. I use liners, so I shake up the beef, flour and seasonings in that before adding vegetables. I cook the mixture on low for about 3 hours before adding liquid (usually Better-than-Bullion low-sodium beef) - to me it's better than cooking beef submerged, especially on low, and maybe similar effect to pre-browning in a skillet, which to me doesn't count as a slow-ccoker recipe. For the last hour I add whole mushrooms and another clove or two of garlic.

I've also turned it into a topnotch soup with finer chopping, more broth and barley (last hour) instead of the potatos...

Edit 5Dec2016> I refer to this recipe for seasoning when making beef stew, but I skip potatoes now and add other lower-carb vegetables so not really the same recipe. Cabbage, fresh green beans, asparagus and kale are all good if added toward the end. I'm strongly tempted to try cauliflower since I love it roasted.  I'm not big on cooked carrots but in this  whole baby carrots are delicious. Also, when boneless short ribs are on sale I use those along with extra lean, sirloin, or organic stew beef. I also hit the seasonings much harder, except salt and bay leaf (one seems to be plenty).

This was absolutely delicious.  The meat was so tender!  I doubled the recipe but followed the ingredients exactly.  I cooked it on low for 7 hours and high for the last 2 hours.  I made this for me and my boyfriend and served it with Italian bread for dipping.  I also added more black pepper to mine, but my boyfriend left it as is and we both really enjoyed it.  It was so easy to make, and it was my first time using my slow cooker.  I didn't do any of the extra steps, like browning the meat first, like other reviewers suggested.  I think it is unnecessary and recipe is good as is.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was going to make this recipe according to others suggestions, but decided to just follow the recipe as is. The only thing that I did was add more veggies. 4 potatoes just wasn't enough and I added a bit more celery as well. Even with the flour this seemed very watery to me. I ended up stirring in a 4oz can of tomato puree and a little sugar. This helped thicken up the broth and added a richer flavor to the stew. It turned out delicious. 

It was very tasty before my additions and probably would have been just as good minus the puree. I just prefer a thicker stew.

text:
Not bad... but not great either. I thought this had VERY little flavor. Also, a lot of meat and not a lot of vegetables. I plan to play with the recipe and try the suggestions of others to spice this up a bit.

EDIT: Tried this again using Corinne's suggestions, plus I added some fresh mushrooms, a can of corn, and a handful of green beans... DELICIOUS! MUCH more flavorful with the extra seasonings. I would say this is 3 stars as is, 5 stars with Corrine/my changes.

Awesome dish, particularly since I'm not a fan of stew in the first place. Followed Corinne's review and coated the beef with flour and sautéed with onions first, added wine, broth Worcester to deglaze, then a packet of McCormick's beef stew seasoning, garlic on top,.. but only cooked 4 hours on high in slow cooker… meat was very tender, veggies and gravy (perfect thickness) … delicious! Thank you for sharing.

text:
Maaaaaaann, there's nothing wrong with this recipe as is!  I just had my first bowl.  I say try it that way first before putting in suggestions.  I cooked mine on low for 8 hours.  Meat DEFINITELY didn't need to be seared first.  If that's your requirement, you might as well use a dutch oven and scrap the whole slow cooker idea.  My beef turned out brown and tender without that.  In the future, I MIGHT play around with the amount of garlic or onions or seasonings added, but this is a very good recipe.....AS IS.

text:
This is the best beef stew I ever made, and even the best I've ever eaten.  I used all of the recommendations made by Corrine.  I was away most of the day, when I came home I did have to add more liquid (I used about a quarter cup of broth) and stir frequently once I got home.  It was done before the 10hours, and it did stick to the sides of the pot while unattended.  I'd definitely recommend greasing the pot ahead of time to speed clean-up if you won't be home to stir it.  I LOVE this stew!!!!!!  I do agree that Corrine should submit her own recipe, it's different enough from the original to warrant a new one.  I've written all of the changes on my copy and will make it again soon.  What wonderful food.

I have a 'crockpot' 6qt i picked up from sears, this was my 1st run at it.

at the end of the day it was pretty good.
however, i would like to know if anyone else found it to be somewhat lacking in terms of 'softness'

cheers.

text:
Flouring and browning the meat is essential for flavor..I cooked on high for 2 hours then reduced to low for several more hours (or over night)..I also add extra potatoes, as the smaller pieces break down they help to thicken the stew...the last hour I added frozen green beans and corn...the stew thickens on its own ... I'll be using the leftovers for a potpie!

I made this the other day with chicken broth because I didn't have any beef broth and it was still delicious! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Per another reviewer; Increase flour to 1/3 cup and substitute seasoned salt for regular salt. Put flour mixture into gallon-sized, zippered bag. Shake beef in bag to coat. Sauté coated beef in 1-2 tablespoons olive oil until browned. Add chopped onion to beef to sauté and soften. Transfer to slow cooker. 2. Mix beef broth  with 1 TABLEspoon Worcestershire and ½ cup red wine. Pour into hot skillet to deglaze, then pour over beef and onions in cooker. 3. Add remaining ingredients with these additions: increase garlic to 2 cloves minced, 2 bay leaves; add 1 packet McCormick's Beef Stew Seasoning.

text:
Very good stew!  My kids really liked it - my 10 yr old son ate 3 bowls!  I didn't use my slow cooker.  Instead, I browned the flour-dredged meat in my cast iron dutch oven then added all the veggies and broth and popped it in 250 degree oven and let it cook all morning and while we were at church.  The house smelled amazing when we got home.  Cook time was about 5 hours.  Next time I would add more liquid as I like more broth in my stew.  With homemade cornbread it was a great meal!

text:
Made the following alterations to the original recipe. I used 1/2 cup flour for the flour mixture. I also pan fried the meat after dredging in flour mixture in olive oil until browned. I used baby carrots instead of sliced regular. I also used 2 15 oz cans of beef broth, two packets of brown gravy mix, 3 tbsp corn starch to thicken and 1/2 cup red cooking wine. I also added 1 tsp of thyme.  delicious!

country:
None
text:
This was great! I made it for my parents and the loved it! I followed the instructions pretty much but used 2 beef boullion cubes with 2 cups water because that's what I had. I didn't have any Worcestershire sauce so I skipped that but I did add a 1/2 cup of Pinot Noir! Oh, and when it was all ready I poured some boiling water in to make sure I had enough for 5 people. The recipe says it serves 6 and I'm sure it does but it was very thick and I wanted it to last longer so I just added the extra hot water. Didn't dilute the taste at all! I'll be making this again for sure.

text:
As Always, I made this recipe exactly as written. When it was done, it seemed too watery, so I added some flour mixture to thicken it up. That was fine. Once I tried it, it def. needed some salt. The flavour was kind of bland, I would have liked more flavour for sure. Next time I will try mixing in some lipton onion soup mix for added flavour.  I did not brown the meat before and it turned out perfect, very very tender, so dont waste your time browning the meat as others suggested.  I think this is a good base recipe for Stew, but needs more flavour!

text:
I am really surprised at the number of 5 star reviews. This recipe is far from special as far as beef stew goes. Don't get me wrong, it is okay, but it needs a lot of doctoring to make it special. My husband and I found it to be pretty bland as it is. If your looking for a beef stew to wow people with, this is not it.

I adjusted this recipe a little because I wanted to use less meat and more veggies, but I prepared it as written.  I don't think any changes are necessary; in fact, I used this recipe because I wanted to throw it all in the crockpot and forget it.  That said, after having it the first night, I did add more salt and pepper for the leftovers, but that's personal preference.

The recipe was cool but i tweeked it a bit. First what i didnt use: Worcestershire. What i did added cilantro, and garlic clove while i was browning the meat (no flour) and i added 1/2 cup of brown sugar and tsp of cayenne to even out the 2 flavors (it really and the right kick to it. I also added a small bag of green giant broccolli (a aquired taste with it) It turned out great!!!

Display Name:
Steve Szat
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WAY too much onion!  Garlic, bay leaves and the other spices involved can enhance the flavor of something without overwhelming it. Onions on the other hand will dominate the flavor of anything unless used sparingly.  Also the celery comes out squishy if cooked from the very beginning, and the carrots come out squishy and bitter tasting.  I would add the celery and carrots near the very end, so that thy are cooked just enough to make them palatable.

4

text:
I had something else in my crockpot so I used my dutch over. I pretty much follow directions. I used a piece of chuck which I cut up and pounded...to insure tenderness, I also added about 1/4 of dry vermouth it adds so much flavor. Rather than chopping the onion I halved it and then cut it in the oppo directions you'd cut if you wanted rings (easier to eat and the small chop is too small for me). I vacuum sealed this for my son in college. He loved it.  I tried a small bowl and it was really flavorful, the meat tender. I added 2+ cups of beef broth.

CWalker57

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner two nights ago... my family are big beef stew eaters, and we ran out of the pre-purchased seasoning packets we like, so I said I would make it from scratch with a high-rated recipe. I upped the flour to 1/3 cup as suggested, then added a little water based on one review that it was "very thick" -- it came out so thin, like a soup. My brothers were upset, but whatever. The biggest problem I had was the lack of flavor. It was so mild my youngest brother was reaching for the Old Bay before he even finished swallowing the first bite. If I made again, I'll try to double the seasonings and see if it gives it some flavor. Otherwise, the meat and veggies all came out tender - easy prep, but too mild and thin a broth for my family's taste.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with some changes and it came out fantastic...I used certified angus chuck roast.  I cut off all the visible fat and made into cubes.  I did take the meat and put in a bag added flour and shook to coat.  Then I browned the meat.  While that was going on, I parboiled the potatoes (not sure if that is needed)  Then I put the meat, potatoes, carrots, celery, diced onions and some frozen pearl onions, in the crockpot.  I added a package of McCormick's Stew seasoning and mixed it with 1 can of beef broth and a 1/2c of red wine.  Also added worcestershire sauce...put on the lid and went to bed.  Woke up to a phenomenal aroma...oh, I also added frozen peas and corn just now. It will be served later this afternoon.

userID:
1733157
Display Name:
Kimberly
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was extremely happy with how this beef stew turned out. I basically followed the recipe exactly except I did things a little differently because I made it on the stovetop. I boiled the meat in about 6 cups of water with a little salt and pepper for about 1 1/2 hrs. first (you can put this on and watch tv while it's boiling). Once the meat was tender I took it out of the stock and let it sit for a couple of min. to dry a little. I followed the recipe and threw the meat, then flour into the pot stirred it around and threw everything else in except the potatoes and beef stock.  I ended up using about 4 cups of beef stock (from the boiled meat) and a cup or 2 of water. In the last 20 min. I put the potatoes in so that they would not be too mushy. I served it over rice and couldn't keep my family out of it. We had enough left over for another night.
Review:

text:
I just made this today.  I had some cheap steaks that I was going to marinate and grill but the weather didn't cooperate...freezing rain yuck!  So I pulled out my trusty slow cooker and began. Cubed the steaks and followed the recipe.  Unfortunately I didn't have beef broth so I used chicken broth and added 2 beef bouillon cubes.  Otherwise followed the recipe except for a few shakes of cayenne pepper, we like it zippy.  Cooked on high for 5 hours then removed the lid for about 45 to thicken an bit more, served over egg noodles and yummy.   I plan to stir a little sour cream into the left overs and server over noodle again for a little different twist.  I think this would be good with the addition of mushrooms also, enjoy

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great stew! It was easy to put together in the slower cooker and cooked perfectly after 6-7 hours on high. We kept the ingredients in larger pieces, so if you cut them smaller, cook for 5-6 hours on high. The spices were a nice start but we thought it needed a boost so we added more Worcestershire, some cajun and a little hot sauce.  This gave it the delicious, rich flavor it needed. Also, we didn't have any bay leaves so they were left out.  I would definitely make this again- it's even better the next day!

Very good stew. I used 1/3 cup flour, 3/4 teaspoon salt, 3/4 teaspoon pepper, 5 potatoes, 2 stalks of celery, 2 cups of beef broth. I also made a 33% less sodium brown gravy packet and added that. Other than that, I followed the recipe. I would add more salt and pepper next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree with others who've said this is a good base. I followed the recipe as written and let it cook 3 hours on high then 3 hours on low in the crock pot. I checked it and found the taste bland, it wasn't thick enough and there wasn't enough liquid. I tweaked by fixing a packet of brown gravy on the stove and adding that, along with a dash of thyme, rosemary, garlic powder and several shakes of seasoned salt. For personal preference, I added about 1 cup of fresh grean beans and a can of mushrooms too. With the changes it is very yummy and the right consistency I was looking for. The meat cooked up nice and tender (I used pre-cut stew meat).

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this using some of the suggestions in the reviews. A bit more flour, a bit more worchestshire sauce. I browned the onions first, then removed those and browned the floury beef, deglazed the pan with the broth.   Overall, VERY yummy! I tasted it early on and was concerned about how salty it was, but that faded after cooking for six hours. Still somewhat salty for us though, we don't use much salt usually so maybe we're more sensitive to it. I'll reduce the salt next time.   Also, I made dumplings and cooked them on the stove using some of the liquid from the pot. So there wasn't enough liquid left in the end, next time I might add a bit more water if dumplings are in the plan.  Overall though, VERY yummy! Very flavourful and tasty. Looking forward to leftovers tomorrow!   Z

text:
This was a great beef stew but yes add more worcestershire sauce to sirloin after you braise it and add garlic, beef broth, wine, onion and beef stew seasoning. I simmered beef with a little corn starch for about 1/2 hour till thick.  Then put potatoes and carrots in the crock pot with the meat.  I added peas and muchrooms at the last just to heat.  Make or buy home made bread of any flavor to go with yum.

text:
Fantastic just the way it is...although the 2nd time I did make a few alterations:  Cut the meat back to 1 pound Add: 1 extra potato 1/4 cup red wine vinegar 1/4 tsp rosemary 1/4 tsp tyme 1/2 tsp parsley increase Worchestershire sauce to 1 Tbsp  Did not brown the meat, but did shake the beef and flour in a ziploc bag rather than mix in the slow cooker. Will defnitely make again!

This stew was pretty good and I really liked the simplicity of it.  My house smelled wonderful when I got home!  I made it as the recipe states with the exception of the celery (because by the time I got to that part I realized I didn't have any).  I would have changed, as one other reviewer recommended, the regular salt to seasoning salt.  The only thing I was dissapointed in is the "gravy".  I guess I was expecting more of an actual gravy like consistency.  And I didn't cook it for any longer than 8 hours because by that time the meat was ready to fall apart.

text:
Perfect after a cold day.  Here's my mods: decreased meat to 1 pkg (1.34 lbs), increased potatoes to 5 small, increased carrots to 6, increased celery to 2 stalks, used 1 can (12 oz) of beef broth.  Mine turned out very thick and hearty.  If you like yours more like a soup I'd recommend an extra can of broth.  Served mine with a few dashes of Tabasco.  Yum!

text:
This recipe wasn't what I expected.  My slow cooker cooks very very fast, so normally I estimate about 1/2 the cook time of the recipe.  I ended up cooking this stew forever and the vegetables never did get cooked all the way through.  The meat, however, overcooked and became very dry.  The broth was thin - not what I would expect from a stew.  The stew tasted okay, but I wouldn't make this again.

text:
This stew was very flavorful. I did follow a few recommendations from other reviewers. I added 1/2 cup of red wine, increased the worcestershire to 1 tablespoon, and added a package of McCormick beef stew seasoning. I had also planned on cooking the beef first to seal it, but ended up not having time. It didn't need it. It tasted great and I loved the simplicity. I left out the potatoes and served it over mashed. Delicious! The stew is very thick.

text:
This was absolutely delicious, just like the beef stew my Mom used to make. I did make a few adjustments....I added about a half a tsp. more of the paprika. Halway through, I added an additional tsp. of salt and an additonal tsp of minced garlic( I tasted it and thought it needed it.)I also added fresh string beans about an hour before it was ready. I cooked on high for 6 hours. The beef was tender and the vegetables perfect! This is a wonderful meal. Thank you so much for this recipe. I looked at other beef stew recipes and finally chose this one to try. I'm glad I did!

text:
Tips: Choose an extremely lean mean.  I bought some pre-cut "beef stew" meat, as it was labeled, and it had a lot of marbling.  When the stew was ready, there was a big layer of grease on top that I had to scoop away once the stew was cooled in the fridge.  Once the oil/fat was gone though, this stew went really well with a dash of Bob's Habanero Hot Sauce.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quite bland as written. Maybe I'll try again with some changes. Family didn't care for it at all.
Update 2/8/2012.  4.5 stars Started making this before realizing I made it before so took a quick look at reviews. First shake the stew meat in seasoned flour (pepper, garlic powder, onion powder) and sautee in olive oil until browned on all sides, remove to crockpot, then sautee onion and 2 cloves of garlic. Next deglaze the pan with 1 can beef broth (14.5 oz) and 1 cup of red wine. Let reduce a little then add a couple of dashes worcesthire, onion soup mix. Add to the crockpot with 2 bay leaves, quartered potatoes and carrots. I cooked mine on high for 5 hours, adding peas 1 hour before done. It was delicious.

text:
This stew turned out excellent my husband loved it too.  I followed the recipe almost exactly.  I added more broth because my large crock-pot seems to dry out if I don't.  Also at the last 30 minutes of cooking time I added some thawed frozen green beans, one small can of tomato sauce and extra (1/4 cup)flour to thicken it.  I left the lid half off and cooked it on high for 30 minutes.

text:
Absolutely spectacular recipe. My husband and I both really enjoyed this! 
I did do a couple of things differently, however! Instead of just beef broth, I used condensed beef broth and then refilled the can, once with water and once with half water half red wine. I also added several sprigs of fresh rosemary and an extra bay leaf, and used a McCormicks Slow Cooker Beef Stew packet. I added extra celery and carrots, and used baby red potatoes. It was AMAZING.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only needed to make enough for two people, but saw that others said that there wasn't enough sauce/gravy, so here's what I did: I only used 1 lb of beef, 2 small potatoes, 2 carrots and 1 stalk of celery.  However, I kept the same amount of everything else that the recipe mentions except I doubled the amount of paprika, garlic, Worchester and used a whole can of beef broth (around 2.5 cups).  End result? Plenty of sauce and pretty tasty.  My husband really liked it, but I thought it could have used a little more spices - hence the 4 stars.  I didn't bother to brown the meat either - just threw everything in the crock pot and let it go for 11 hours.  This was super-easy and pretty good!

Display Name:
Florence

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent stew, a success with guests. I made modifications as follows:  I browned the beef as suggested by the previous reviewer, and deglazed the pan with a can of low sodium beef broth and about half a cup of dark beer.  I added more garlic and Worcestershire sauce than in the original recipe.  For veggies, I used three large potatoes, three large carrots, a large parsnip, four smallish turnips, and about half an acorn squash.  I cooked it for about six hours on high.  Near the end of the cooking time, I threw in, on a whim, about 1/3 of a jar of cornichons (chopped up) and pickled onions.  The pickles lost their flavor, but the onions added a nice touch.  If I ever do that again, I may add a bit of mustard and a little more beer. I finished it off with about half a cup minced parsley.  It was a perfect do-ahead meal for a rainy November day.

text:
I made this recipe for my husband last week.  The stew came out good - although I needed to add a little more liquid to the pot because it started to get a little sticky.  In the end - the stew was good and could have used a bit of red wine or more Worcestershire.  I ended up pouring the stew into small crocks and added puffed pastry.  My husband thought that was great!
